name: Mossfield, Frank, MP
text:
—When I was speaking on this States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 2000 last evening, I made the comment that the figures on how each school will benefit will not be known for another month, yet we are supposed to pass this bill as soon as possible. This concern about lack of information goes to the amendment that the opposition has moved and which I support. It also goes to the adjournment to this bill we sought last evening in an effort to ensure that all the information was available so that it could be debated in full. How are we supposed to fully debate this bill when we do not know the full consequences of its implementation? The trouble is that all school funding is tied up in this bill and if it is not passed then there will be no money for any of the schools. `Pass the bill or no schools get funding' is essentially what this minister and the government are saying. Where I come from, that is called blackmail. It is yet another example of the heavy-handedness and arrogance of this government. 
One of the most significant changes in this legislation is the move away from the notion of achieving a common standard of resource provisions based on the needs of the students towards a model in which government funding happens first and then parents add on what they can raise by private means—donations, bequests and private investments. Unfortunately, for many parents what they can raise privately is not nearly enough to provide the kinds of resources that schools need. This general lack of resources may be the reason that there is still a large number of Australian teenagers dropping out of the education system. In a review of the government's Jobs Pathway programs by the Dusseldorp Skills Forum, a researcher with that forum, Mr John Spierings, has written:
One hundred and eighty thousand, or 14 percent of teenagers [aged 15 to 19] are trying to negotiate the much-vaunted knowledge economy without even the fundamental building blocks of full-time work or participation in further education or training.
As reported in the Australian newspaper, Spierings expressed concern that `in a robust economy, very significant numbers of young people are not enjoying the benefits of growth'. The Dusseldorp report suggests that Australian schools are haphazard in providing career advice to students and that some schools appear nervous of outside career counsellors trying to keep in school children who are not performing academically or trying to link them to jobs.
The lack of qualified careers advisers has been a concern for some time. I was a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training which brought down a report entitled Youth employment: a working solution in September 1997. It was quite clear that one of the great concerns that a lot of young people have, and a lot of career advisers themselves have, is the lack of qualified career advisers in our education system. This is a specialised field that needs quite serious attention by the federal government. The suggestion put forward by the shadow minister for education, the member for Dobell, that an incoming Labor government would fund professional development for teachers, would go to overcoming this problem of lack of qualified career advisers. The following quote from the committee report highlights the concern that that committee had on that occasion:
The first major problem with careers guidance for young people is that many teachers are ill equipped for the careers guidance role. Teachers, careers guidance officers and students who the Committee spoke with all agreed. It is a systemic problem and not the fault of individual teachers who may, without any specific training, find themselves the careers teacher simply because their teaching load allows time for it. Most are left to draw on their own life experiences, which in many cases is school to university and back to school, when advising students. Typically, there will be one careers teacher, who may or may not be full-time, for as many as 1,000 to 1,200 students.
I draw attention to the need for specialised career advisers because, in the Dusseldorp report that I referred to, A window into the future, two concerns were continually raised. Firstly, the long-term unemployment trend—and I think we can say the uncertainty of employment for all Australian but particularly for young people—creates the possibility of continued youth unemployment. Secondly, young people are poorly prepared for the job market. These are the two issues which have come out from this very recent report which the government themselves have endorsed. 
I move on to the area of special education for students in the bill. Special education for students with disabilities is a particular and growing problem area for both government and non-government schools. The Howard government has broken a 1996 promise—another one—to increase special education funding by $16.5 million. This bill contains only modest increases in funding for students with disabilities in non-government schools and does not increase the overall level of funding for students in government schools. Recent court decisions have strengthened the legal obligations, under antidiscrimination legislation, for non-government schools to enrol students with disabilities if requested by parents. I believe that non-government schools have indicated that they are happy to enrol students with disabilities provided the government funding is adequate to meet the high additional costs they face in meeting the student needs. I think we can appreciate the considerable cost involved in this area of providing additional facilities for students with disabilities.
The move from a system of funding based on schools' total resource levels to one based on socioeconomic status will require the funding of special education to be overhauled. Current per capita funding arrangements by the Commonwealth provide the greatest level of assistance to the wealthiest schools—$2,972 extra per student—tapering to nothing for those in the needier category. Most Catholic schools receive $208 per primary student and $306 extra for secondary students. I believe that negotiations with the Catholic Education Commission have been carried out correctly and I do not think there is any suggestion that there has been any underhand move in the negotiations. But I believe that the Catholic schools system still faces a long-term funding problem, and I do not think at this moment that the scheme that has been agreed to will solve its long-term problem.
This bill provides extra per capita funding of $522 for all non-government students with disabilities. Moreover, the 5,000 students who currently receive a higher rate will have that maintained at an annual cost of $3.5 million per annum. For government schools this bill has a single per capita rate for special education funding of $102. The bill also provides, for the first time, establishment grants to help new schools, regardless of need, as well as recurrent funding for distance education at the lowest SES funding level. This bill and the education policies of this government simply do not make sense. The wealthier schools get huge increases in government funding while the poorest, most needy schools get next to nothing. The sliding scale of payment is sloping in the wrong direction. It is a bit like the government's tax cuts when it introduced the GST: the wealthiest got the most and the poor got next to nothing. Make the rich richer so that more crumbs fall from the table for those below—that seems to be the logic behind this and the other policies of the government.
This debate is about education. It is ultimately about the future of our nation. The questions we must ask ourselves with any piece of legislation are: will this improve the lot of ordinary Australians? Will people be better off? Will it improve the country? This piece of legislation has its positives: schools in the non-government sector are getting more money. More money in education is never wrong—but at what cost? The long-term consequences of this bill are disturbing, to say the least. The policies of this government, as typified in this bill, are divisive and ultimately harmful to society.
The Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs obviously does not believe in public education. He must believe that the government has no place in providing education to the community. Why else would he invent something like the enrolment benchmark adjustment system? The sole purpose of this is to defund public schools. The EBA system is one where it does not matter if your enrolments increase, you still lose funding. If the proportion of students in private schools increases compared with the number of students in government schools, funding to government schools is reduced. Take Victoria, for example: enrolments up by 7,767 and funding down by $6 million since the introduction of the EBA. In my state of New South Wales, a mere 230 fewer students will cost New South Wales $16.6 million. On the other hand, in Tasmania, where the proportion of students in the public system has actually risen, has the EBA resulted in increased funding? No, it has not. The EBA is a one-way penalty scheme designed with no other purpose than to cut funding from government schools. The education pie has shrunk since this government came to office. More than that, the proportion of funding to government schools has also declined dramatically. In 1996 the government spent 41.5 per cent of the education budget on government schools; by 2003 that figure will have dropped to a mere 32.2 per cent—a much smaller slice of a much smaller pie.
debate_title: <title>STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) BILL 2000</title>

name: Lindsay, Peter, MP
text:
—I rise to address the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 2000. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will know that I represent in this parliament Australia's largest tropical city. In fact, I represent the twin cities of Townsville and Thuringowa. In representing the educational community in Townsville and Thuringowa, I represent what would probably be a microcosm of what happens elsewhere in the country.
—Hear, hear!
—I thank the member for Leichhardt and say to the honourable member that Townsville and Cairns are a lot alike. We have in Townsville and Thuringowa a whole range of schools: from wealthy to poor, from state to private, Catholic and indigenous schools—we have the lot. I find very interesting what has happened over the last four years that the coalition has been in government and what has happened to the schools in my electorate. There has been a consistent improvement across the board. I say that with absolute knowledge of what has happened. There has been a consistent improvement in the private, Catholic and government schools. We hear the opposition criticising the government over what the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs is doing in relation to school funding, yet here we have on the public record the evidence for everybody to see: that the school system is improving. It is improving in the state arena but it is also improving in the private arena, and surely that is a pretty good outcome.
Earlier in the piece, as we saw with the government schools system, its schools were losing their customers. What do I mean by that? The parents were voting with their feet; they were taking their children away from state schools. Why were they doing that? Why were they leaving the state schools? That is the question that the government schools have been asking themselves and, to their credit, that is the question that they have been responding to. In responding to the fact that parents now have choice, they have been able to examine themselves and find out what they were doing wrong and how they could improve service to their customers.
There were lots of issues in the government schools. For many years they had been very comfortable that the children would come along every year and enrol and they would do the job, until the parents found out that there was a better way. There are some things that are not terribly wonderful to talk about in the parliament. The state system had difficulty in controlling some of the difficult students. The state schools say, quite rightly, `We have to accept every student who comes to our door. How can we not have difficult students?' But now we see the state system responding to that and getting all sorts of mechanisms which in fact help those difficult students to adjust and indeed help them to be a valuable contributing part of the school community. Surely that is a good outcome. 
I refer to some specific examples. I opened two new blocks at the Annandale State School recently. It was $2.5 million, I think, of federal government money into a government school for new capital infrastructure. Annandale State School is as good a school as you will find anywhere in the Commonwealth of Australia, government or private. It is as good as any school you will find, because the government system is now responding to its customers. Similarly with the Willows State School. I pay tribute to Mrs Carol Buchanan, the principal there. She and her school community have a little motto for the school called `The Willows Way'. In everything that they do, they ask their students, `Is this the Willows way?' It certainly resonates. And that school is as good as you will find anywhere in the primary school community in Townsville-Thuringowa. In the state high school system, I pay tribute to Gail Kirkman, the principal of the Northern Beaches State High School, which is as good a secondary school as you will find anywhere in the system. Yes, I know that we have private schools that have a parent body that are well off. We have schools like Townsville Grammar, the Cathedral School and so on. I think that the facilities that are provided there are very good as well, but of course the government does not provide the same level of support to those very wealthy schools as it does to other schools.
I see the opposition jumping up and down and asking why it is that we are giving all this money to private schools and indeed Catholic schools. I go to Ryan Catholic Community School in Townsville and I see Ryan school taking the poorest students. It is a Catholic school where a poor student does not require fees to go to school, and that school does a marvellous job for its particular community. So I see some terrific results out of Dr Kemp's forward-looking policies in education in relation to providing choice, and the results speak for themselves; they are there on the ground. None of this class distinction claptrap that goes on from the opposition—everybody can choose which school they want to go to, and the standards in the various systems are rising so that they will equalise out and people will have the opportunity to choose which school they wish to attend. 
I note that today there was an item on the news wire from the National Council of Independent Schools Associations accusing the opposition of playing politics with families by attempting to delay a controversial education funding bill. This is the bill we are talking about today. That occurred last night when an opposition member moved a motion in an attempt to delay the bill. That has ramifications that I guess will hurt the parent communities who have to prepare their own family budgets on the fees that the schools charge. It is unfair to families who work so hard to educate their children. Why is the opposition attempting to hurt families who choose to go through an educational institution that is not a government school? Why is that? The answer might lie in the politics of class distinction or it might lie in the politics of unionism and who controls the Labor Party. Wherever it lies, it is wrong. It is time that the opposition recognised that we should have a community that has choice and that we should come to expect, as I believe we can, parallel school systems that each provide exactly the same quality of education that you can get from any other school. 
I pause to reflect—the member for Leichhardt will back me on this—that it was the opposition who opposed and opposed Dr Kemp's visionary views on the fact that kids ought to be able to read and write when they leave school. That is what it comes down to: they ought to be able to read, write and add up. When we came to government, we saw the facts about the percentage of kids who could not read and write properly—
—Shocking. 
—It was shocking; you are right. I think it was to Dr Kemp's eternal credit that he took the hard view. He said, `We are going to fix this.' We were fought by the unions in the Labor states through their not going on with the benchmarking processes, but at the end of the day the government is committed to wanting our kids to come out of school actually being able to read, write and add up.
—And we got results.
—And we got tremendous results. Those results are now being translated through into the indigenous schools. The Scaffolding project that the minister unveiled at Shalom Christian College in my electorate, one of the very fine indigenous schools that we have, is a landmark. He referred to it in the parliament late last week.
—Who started Shalom College? It was brought in under Working Nation with Reverend Blackman.
—Who is a great supporter of the government. In just one year, this project brought forward indigenous youngsters with very poor literacy standards to a level three years above their original level. I agree with you that Shalom is a fantastic college—
—It was a Labor initiative.
—And it was supported by me. It has an aged care facility as well, so it is terrific. In supporting the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 2000, I am pleased to see that the Commonwealth is renewing its commitment to school education in the 2001-04 quadrennium. Under this bill, funding for Commonwealth programs of financial assistance to the states and territories for government and non-government schools is secured. The funding will be secured; that is why it is important to get this bill through the parliament. The bill implements a number of decisions made in the 1999-2000 budget including: the introduction of the new socioeconomic status, SES, based funding arrangements for non-government schools; additional funding and consequential changes to funding arrangements for the Short-Term Emergency Assistance Program, now renamed the Schools Transitional Emergency Assistance Program; the introduction of a revised structure for Commonwealth programs for targeted assistance for schools; and improved accountability arrangements for the Commonwealth schools program.
As you would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, the coalition government has a proud record of improving Australia's education system, which was badly neglected under Labor. This bill acknowledges the right of Australian parents to choose the most appropriate schools for their children. It supports the devolution of decision making about education to where it belongs: to the parents and to the communities. It includes communities such as my community of Townsville-Thuringowa and your community of Cairns and Cape York, Member for Leichhardt. Even in tiny places in Cape York, this legislation will devolve that responsibility. It will ensure that we have an education system that is responsive to students' needs. This bill is a major investment in our children and our society. By providing additional funds to schools, particularly those schools in the neediest areas, the government will be able to seek improved outcomes from schools, which will provide a brighter future for Australian students. Those opposite talk about making Australia the knowledge nation, but we are already doing it. This bill will ensure that Australia will be in a better position to make major contributions to our global future and to continue in the fine Australian tradition of innovation and skill. To provide these commitments, the government will appropriate in excess of $18 billion for the coming quadrennium.
This is historic legislation, as it includes provision for the new socioeconomic status based funding arrangements. The historic reform provides a more open, objective and fair approach for funding non-government schools. Under the new arrangements, general recurrent funding will be distributed according to need, and schools serving the neediest communities will receive the greatest financial support. This means that parents from all income levels will now have a realistic capacity to choose the most appropriate schooling for their children. Unlike the previous system, this new model will be more responsive to the financial needs of the school. It will not discourage private investment in education, and schools will be able to raise private income without penalty. This bill provides financial assistance for schools to attract students from low income families. The bill offers parents choices which were not available in the past—surely that is a good outcome. The bill allows for the increased funding to schools to be phased in over the quadrennium. Schools that are funded on their SES scores will have their increased funding phased in at the rate of 25 per cent of the increase each year, so by 2004 schools will be fully funded at a new level. It is important to be aware that under this bill no school will be financially disadvantaged by the move to the new SES funding system. No school will be disadvantaged. Under the old system, schools that would otherwise have had their funding reduced under the new arrangements will have their year 2000 per capita entitlements maintained, with the year 2000 dollar rates adjusted annually in line with the latest AGSRC figures.  
During the 1998 election, the Howard government gave a commitment to protect Catholic systems. This will be honoured under the new SES based funding arrangements. Approved Catholic school systems will be funded on a basis that essentially preserves in real terms the per capita equivalent of their current funding categories in the year 2000. New schools that are not part of the Catholic system will have their entitlement to Commonwealth funding assessed according to an SES based measure of need. This means that new schools that are attended by students from less affluent communities will also be eligible to receive a higher level of Commonwealth assistance. Additional funding for schools experiencing severe financial hardship, or facing problems of viability during the transition arrangements, and establishment grants will be available to assist new non-government schools with costs incurred in their formative years, thus enabling them to be competitive with existing schools.
The Howard government believes in choice and equality in our education system, and I referred to that earlier in this address to the parliament. Another winner from this bill are students from distance education schools, and that is certainly something that is prominent in Northern Australia. This bill provides recurrent funding for students receiving education from non-government schools. The coalition government is committed to improving literacy and numeracy standards for all students. A major policy priority of the coalition is to achieve real improvement in the literacy and numeracy skills of Australian children. I would like to pause for a minute and pay tribute to the teachers and staff at the Garbutt State School in Townsville. Garbutt has a very high indigenous component in its school population. The work that is being done there has resulted in national awards for the Garbutt State School for getting these young indigenous students up to speed and making sure that their literacy and numeracy standards are as good as they can be.
Labor failed to improve educational standards. After 13 years, 30 per cent of school students failed to meet minimum acceptable literacy and numeracy standards. Labor chose not to address this vital issue. That is why I am pleased to support this bill. The revised structure combines the literacy and numeracy grants to schools programs and the special education schools support fixed and per capita grants into the strategic assistance for improving student outcomes program. This program is aimed at helping schools and school authorities to improve student learning outcomes for educationally disadvantaged students, particularly in literacy and numeracy, and at helping school authorities and government centres to improve the educational participation in outcomes for students with disabilities. The bill also combines the priority and community languages program into the language other than English program and simplifies administrative arrangements under this program. The funds made available will continue to be aimed at helping schools and their authorities, government educational institutions and other bodies to improve the teaching and learning of languages other than English. 
This bill recognises the rights of parents and children: for parents, the right to choose the type of education they want for their kids and, for children, the right to quality education through improved outcomes for all students. Labor goes on and on about creating a knowledge nation. The unions still dictate Labor's education policy or lack thereof. Even one of their own has said that they stuffed it up after 13 years. Labor could not get it right. It ignored the serious problems of numeracy and literacy, and vocational education and training.
Opposition members interjecting—
—Thank you for being a good audience. My time is about to expire. I appreciate the audience that I have attracted, and I strongly support the bill before the parliament this afternoon.
debate_title: <title>STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) BILL 2000</title>

name: Beazley, Kim, MP
text:
—Education is at the heart of the knowledge nation. Every kid has the right to fulfil his or her potential. Every kid has the right to creativity, to be excited by well-motivated, knowledgable teachers and a good curriculum. Every student has the right to good opportunities for the completion of their schooling. We in this place have a duty to reverse the appalling completion rate for our school students which has developed in recent years. Fortunately, the election of state Labor governments around the country is beginning to turn that trend back to where it was before the advent of Liberal state governments and then a federal Liberal government in the early nineties and mid-nineties. But it is only their efforts which are turning this trend around, and their efforts alone are insufficient to bring us to the sorts of levels of completion rates that we will need if we are going to be able to be both a happy society and a competitive nation this century.
These objectives can be achieved only through an education policy dedicated to the health of the whole system and not driven by blind ideology. The Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Dr Kemp, has been exposed over and over again in his obsession to damage and diminish public education. It is hard to understand how a man in his position can hold the public system—that covering 70 per cent of our young people—in such low regard. What is it that has convinced him that education must be returned to the days when the only road to success was to choose wealthy parents? The only way you could justify his proposed changes would be to think that this country was so well served by its education system, churning out such a surfeit of excellent school leavers in all areas of major economic need, that we should limit the supply. Does anyone think that that description applies to Australia today? No, it is all a case of ideological obsession.
As soon as he got the job in 1996, Dr Kemp set out to diminish the public system. We had evidence of it last year when we got a copy of his leaked submission to cabinet that would have resulted in $100,000 university fees, with the poor being forced into loans at market interest rates. We know that he has been motivated by blind ideology since at least 1991. We know this because we have another remarkable leaked document of a coalition meeting from June of that year. At that meeting Dr Kemp said:
... noted that the Coalition sought to encourage students to move from government to non-government schools and was committed to the funding of non-government schools.
At that meeting it was agreed that Dr Kemp would report back on: 
non-government schools—whether additional expenditure could be offset by reductions in grants to government schools and in untied grants.
So that was his strategy as far back as his opposition days, nearly a decade ago—to get Australian children out of the public sector and into private schools, and to find the extra money by taking it away from the public schools. He has sought to demonise the public schools, demonise the teachers in public schools and diminish their actual resources so that they would find it difficult to achieve the bars that he set them to jump, putting those resources into a select section of private schools. And this is just what he has done with his enrolment benchmark adjustment in which the states lose federal funding if the public school share of the state's enrolment numbers falls. This is a clever financial disincentive to state governments. It is a clever mechanism for diminishing state schools with a spurious argument that conjures some sort of notion of equity as you go through it. He even had the hide to stand up in this place in question time the other day and say this was not an education measure. What else was it supposed to be? It certainly featured as an education savings measure in the 1996 budget.
The States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill gets rid of the old 12 categories of funding for non-government schools. Instead, it introduces a so-called socioeconomic status for funding. Dr Kemp has had a lot of difficulty in explaining how this would work. It seems, from the evidence of officials in parliamentary committees, that the upshot would be that the top 62 category 1 schools in Australia will be the major beneficiaries. The ability of these schools to fund themselves, through their $10,000 fees, through graduand gifts, parental donations and the like, will no longer be taken into account. Their massive resource capabilities would no longer be taken into account. Instead, the addresses of parents would be examined to see whether they fall into wealthy or poor areas, as determined by a four-year-old limited census survey.
Under this system, children of millionaires who nevertheless live in relatively poor areas, such as many rural regions of Australia, will be deemed to be needy and funding to the school would be increased. Elite private schools that admit some of `the underprivileged' on scholarships will be rewarded by extra funding. It is clearly designed to get as many kids as possible out of public schools and into private schools. But this is not Dr Kemp's only motive. This is because his new funding formula does not give to private schools equally.
As many independent commentators have spotted in this legislation, the poor Catholic schools, by far the biggest group in the private school sector, are a loser in this system. We support the decision of the Catholic Education Commission to opt out of David Kemp's new system. The Catholic commission is trying to provide for the nation's 1,600 Catholic schools, some of which are among the poorest of non-government schools. We believe it is totally unfair that they should receive only an extra $157 for each Catholic school student, compared to an average $900 increase for each pupil in elite category 1 schools. The minister likes to claim he has the Catholics' support. The new funding formula has been politely received by the Catholic education authorities. They are always polite in dealing with Commonwealth governments when there is any increase at all in the resources being given to them. But make no mistake: they are alert to the dangers of the new so-called socioeconomic status—or SES—funding. As the Deputy Chair of the National Catholic Education Commission, Father Tom Doyle, said on August 22:
We would still maintain that the SES model in itself was not sufficient and that it needs modification ... that is why we talk about SES plus things like resource indicators and resource availabilities.
Precisely what I have been talking about. We have had it confirmed by high-level education officials that the top 62 schools in Australia will get $50 million extra to share, while the 1,600 Catholic schools receive only $100 million per annum extra. Top category 1 schools, like the ones most of the government frontbench went to, do very nicely, while those in the local Sacred Heart Convent, like the ones at least 40 per cent of my frontbench went to, hardly get enough for a couple of library books. It looks as if David Kemp has taken a spiritual point from St Matthew's Gospel literally as an issue in public policy:  
    For unto every one that hath shall be given, and he shall have abundance: but from him that hath not shall be taken away, even that which he hath.
The origins of David Kemp's position lie deep in history. His views are of a piece with the Liberal Party's opposition to state aid—a debate resolved by my father in the 1970s. The Liberals opposed needs based funding then, and today Dr Kemp has found a formula to try to get back to those days. I remember them well. I remember my father telling me that Malcolm Fraser leant across the dispatch box while he introduced his bills and said to him, `You will not get these bills. They will be defeated in the Senate.' What he was saying was that the poor schools of Australia would not get that funding. They got it after my father was hospitalised with a heart attack, when Lionel Bowen, who in many ways is a more worldly figure than my father, went around to the National Party and gave them a list of the Catholic schools in their electorates which he intended to visit to explain to them the consequences of the coalition's policies. And so it went through.
We in the Labor Party, as evidenced by the fact that we are the authors, are not opposed to private schools receiving a decent share of federal funds. My father's reforms ensured that people who pay their taxes to see a proportion of their money go to the schools attended by their children get some just reward—it is only fair. But we do not support the inequalities in David Kemp's legislation, and we know they are against every wish of ordinary, decent Australians. We know that education is a fundamental concern of Australians and that it is getting more important in this society to get a good education. What we in the Labor Party believe, unlike our opponents, is that a good education is not just a private desire; it is a public investment for the public good. There is simply nothing more important for the future of this country than a good education system. We know, although our government cannot seem to grasp it, that we cannot afford to let our education system run down.
The public system, which the majority of Australians will continue to attend, lies at the heart of our commitment to education. We need every child from every family to get the basic building blocks to allow them to take their place in the revolution going on in our workplaces. We are already 30,000 information technology workers short in this country. We desperately need more science and engineering graduates, as well as more and better teachers in `enabling sciences'. Does David Kemp think they are all going to come out of 62 elite schools? Whenever we raise public education as a national concern, he comes in and makes patronising comments about how the government has some technical education programs or traineeships for the poorer areas of Australia. Of course, many of these programs were begun by Labor in any case. We agree that these programs are essential and that this country needs well-educated, technical trainees. But we need much more than that. We cannot just sit back and hope that somehow we will muddle through, that our education system may, through luck, manage to produce enough high-technology, science-literate, innovative and adaptable workers for the knowledge economy.
As our competitors around the world know, it takes planning, it takes investment and it takes something this government has never had—a commitment to equality of opportunity. The population of this nation is too small to go backwards to David Kemp's notion of the elite—those who deserve the best because they were born into the right families. We need to get the best out of everyone—the kids of struggling working families in the west of Sydney; children of farmers battling to break even in the bush; and sons and daughters of Australians who believe in the public system, who pay their taxes and who want their schools improved. 
The minister often comes into this House and takes refuge in what he perceives to be the failure of public school teachers, yet these people are the backbone of many communities in this nation. For modest pay, these teachers take on big classes, literacy and numeracy problems, sports and music needs, discipline issues and a rapidly changing curriculum. Besides those, these folk take on many of the essential organisational requirements—the sporting, social and voluntary activities—of the towns of regional Australia. I well remember when the Teachers Union in Western Australia organised a work-to-rule to pursue their case. The people who were first to complain about it were all the country football teams that lost their coaches and the local fire brigades that lost their workers. One after the other these teachers, so demonised by this minister, had their full public value drawn to the attention of the bulk of the Australian community in generally Liberal voting electorates.
We all know there are problems. As the government's chief scientist reported recently, many teachers are being forced to teach subjects they are not trained in. It is impossible to excite growing kids into an interest in science and maths—the building blocks of the knowledge revolution—if you do not have any background in these subjects and you are two or three lessons ahead of them. All of the latest research suggests that the best way to improve education is not to change the state and private split, as Dr Kemp believes, but to improve the subject expertise of teachers and to attract high calibre graduates to teaching, with a particular but not exclusive emphasis on science, maths and information technology skills.
We have already begun to address these problems. We have announced details of our teacher development contracts and our teacher excellence scholarships. We will work with communities in disadvantaged areas to introduce education priority zones to lift the quality of education in the areas that need it most. We will assist students, teachers and parents through new technology, with our Learning Gateway web site, giving instant access to a huge range of educational services and a thorough understanding to parents about where their children are going, the sort of curriculum that they are dealing with, where that curriculum will take them and the sorts of tests they will be obliged to confront. That is real community knowledge and community participation, and it will underpin those priority zones, which will be community based. Communities will determine their needs. That need may be for additionally qualified teachers, it may be for special literacy programs or it may be for mentoring programs into ultimate traineeships or onto university. There is a whole range of things—one size does not fit all—in our communities, and this will address them. We will double the number of educational research scholarships at universities, an idea recently taken up by the chief scientist. Beyond this, we will introduce a new category of fellowships to keep the best and brightest Australians here.
Here is something that will be popular with almost everyone in the debate: we will abolish the hated enrolment benchmark adjustment. We will not penalise our public system because of an ideological fixation. Here is the central issue at stake: the minister has to explain to Australians, in a context of scarce public resources, how giving $50 million to category 1 private schools will be a more effective policy than improving opportunities for ordinary kids throughout this country. Until we get an answer to this, we will be seeking to adjourn debate on this legislation. It is an insult for this parliament to be asked to pass a $22 billion bill before the government provides detailed final figures on the bill's true financial effect. We are supposed to be the checkpoint of the accountability of legislation before us. If we cannot get a complete and clear picture of how this very confused model produces a particular outcome for individual schools, no-one can get it. We have an absolute right as the House of Representatives to demand that prior to passage of these bills. 
We are not alone in our criticisms. If the minister does not want to listen to us, there are others he might heed. Take, for example, Victorian Supreme Court Justice Frank Vincent, who is also Chancellor of Victoria University in Melbourne's western suburbs. Justice Vincent, who came from a battling family himself and went to a state school, said on 31 August:
I am decidedly uncomfortable with any of the processes which are increasing the practical discrimination against the poor in this country, and I fear that might be happening at the present time with these new funding structures ... There were, for a period of time, avenues of opportunity for people such as myself, and I'm concerned that those avenues are being cut off dramatically as time progresses.
It is an extraordinary statement from a man in a position to judge. We are going backwards in equity. There has been widespread community outcry about the unfairness of the minister's aims. The Melbourne Age, in a blistering editorial, said: 
    The government's new socioeconomic status funding system for private schools, which will provide the massive windfall gains for the richest schools, will only entrench the disparities within our education system. It is not in the best interests of the nation to go down this path.
The Australian, often a supporter of the government's market driven policies, was equally scathing:
    The reforms are tantamount to conceding defeat in the battle to improve the quality of education available to all. The Government has a duty to spend taxpayers' money where it does most good, for those who need it most.  Dr Kemp's system leaves the elite the richer and education the poorer.
This is a massive indictment. The commentators know it, the education industry knows it and students, teachers and parents know it. It is time for the government to wake up to itself. Under the Howard government, the policy—as in so many other areas—is for the rich to get richer, the poor to get poorer and the middle to be squeezed. Under the Howard education regime, it's back to the four Rs—Reading, 'Riting and 'Rithmetic for the Rich. That is the antithesis to Labor's approach, and that is why we want this debate adjourned—so we can have a proper discussion on the public investment issues associated with education.

name: Macfarlane, Ian, MP
text:
—I rise to speak on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 2000. May I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his opening comments if for no other part of his speech. I certainly agree that we should be aspiring to be a knowledge nation and that every student deserves the opportunity for an education. I disagree strongly, though, that if education in the government sector falls down it is completely the fault of a federal government. I say this about Labor: when they get into state government, they know how to cut back funding. The increase in the federal budget for education is 4.2 per cent. The member for Lilley may well remember from his experience in assisting state governments that this year the increase in the Queensland state government budget for education is 0.8 per cent. Let me say those figures again: federal government increase, 4.2 per cent; Labor state government in Queensland increase, 0.8 per cent.
It has always been the responsibility of a state government to look after government education, and it has always been the responsibility of the federal government, in the main, to look after non-government education. That is how you create the health of the whole system. It is not, as the Leader of the Opposition asserts, through attacking one section while you build up the other.
—There are no category 1 schools in Toowomba! 
—You do not strengthen the weak by weakening the strong, member for Batman. I can tell you that when Labor were in power they did everything they could to destroy the non-government sector of education in this nation. We are about building up both sides of education. We in the coalition believe in a choice in education. Whether the Premier of Queensland wants to send his son to Brisbane Grammar is not in the equation I am talking about tonight. The equation I am talking about tonight is the one that gives parents freedom of choice in which school their children are educated. One of my daughters is educated at a government school and the other is educated at a non-government school. Both those schools provide exceptional levels of education. I defy anyone to show me a better school than Toowoomba East State School, under the leadership of Alan Jarrott.
We heard a tirade against the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs from the Leader of the Opposition that was completely unjustified. This government policy we are debating at the moment has never been driven by ideological obsession; it has been driven by a desire to bring equity, fairness and transparency to the education system. We want to ensure that schools are given ample opportunity to provide a standard of education that is fair and equitable. I noted the comments of the Leader of the Opposition about Catholic schools. Yes, they are happy. The reason they are happy is that they will get $8.15 billion out of this federal government, of the $13 billion that is allocated to non-government schools. Of course, all educators want more. Every school I go to wants more money. It does not matter whether it is a government or a non-government school. What we as a federal government are doing is addressing those needs.
Last night during the adjournment debate I discussed some of the great programs that the federal government is involved in. I spoke about the $529,000 that we have just given to a government school at Fairview Heights in my electorate, the $70,000 that we have given to Sacred Heart School in Toowoomba and the $170,000 that we have given to the St Francis de Sales school in Clifton. What that tells me—and I know from looking in my diary that I am going to the Wilsonton School when parliament adjourns—is that we are continuing to fund on a fair and equitable basis, with a commitment to equal opportunity.
We, like the Leader of the Opposition, want to see all schools improved. We want to see the standard we have at the moment improved. What I see in government schools in my electorate is already an exceptional standard of schooling. Attending the speech nights at the end of last year—perhaps something that many of us do not look forward to, a string of late nights in a row, but I can say that I get a great deal of satisfaction in going along and seeing the potential that these young people have and the great education they receive—my observations were that the government schools in my electorate are easily on a par with the non-government schools.
That is not to say that there is not a shift in my electorate, as there is in Australia, towards non-government schools. That is part of offering the choice. I think that the Leader of the Opposition may echo his words when he says that governments have a responsibility to spend taxpayers' money where it does the most good. We are certainly doing that. We are doing it in such a way that those parents who make the decision to educate their children in non-government schools are actually saving the taxpayers money. For every child whose education is supported by the federal government and by Australia's taxpayers, for every dollar that we put in there, we save 50c, compared with what we spend on a student who studies in a government school. That is about delivering maximum bang for your buck. That is an issue that the Labor Party in this parliament do not understand. It is an issue that they had extraordinary difficulty in understanding when it came to health insurance. We make no bones about the fact that a government has a responsibility to ensure that the choice remains for parents and that, if parents make that choice—and many of the parents who make a choice to use non-government schools do so at great financial hardship—we as a government have a responsibility to support them. 
 In supporting this bill to implement the government's commitment to maintaining stability in Commonwealth funding for primary and secondary education in Australia for the 2001-2004 quadrennium, I emphasise the federal government's commitment to giving parents the choice of whether their children are educated in a government or a non-government school. I am therefore happy to reiterate on the record, and I have probably done so already, that the federal government is committed to ensuring that choice and to ensuring that all Australian children receive the best education possible.
A fair funding model is vital if we are to meet the challenge of continuing to achieve our commitment to delivering the best possible education for our nation's students. The answer to this challenge lies in the introduction of the SES system. The SES funding assessment arrangements are designed to more fairly, simply and transparently determine the funding needs of non-government schools, at no cost to government schools. Rather than using the schools' own resource levels, as measured by the current and clearly discredited ERI system—a system that unfairly froze funding to non-government schools for up to 15 years in some cases—SES assessment will consider the parents' capacity to pay.
I know the Labor Party has difficulty in understanding this process, so I will say it again. SES funding is money which goes to schools according to the independently assessed needs of families whose children are enrolled there. I cannot for the life of me understand why the Labor Party is running around telling everyone that money is going to the wealthy schools. The Leader of the Opposition quoted in his address this mythical figure of 62 schools. The Labor Party is running around saying that all this money is going to the wealthy schools. This is wedge politics at its cheapest—at its cheapest. We hear the rhetoric coming from the Leader of the Opposition that the rich are getting richer and the poor are getting poorer. Is he so desperate now that he has to resort to dividing this nation? Isn't leadership, in the true sense of the word, about uniting the nation, about bringing the systems together? Isn't that what leadership is about? I must admit my disappointment at seeing the Leader of the Opposition stoop so low.
It is unfortunate that Labor and some of those who supposedly represent the many tremendous Australian teachers have done so much to try to discredit what the federal government is doing. In that situation, I am proud and pleased that the coalition government remains totally committed to the stability of the education system, while the Labor Party continues to try to pull down the non-government sector. To illustrate the point, there was recently a letter to the editor in the Toowoomba Chronicle, in my electorate of Groom, which espoused this theory. Surprise, surprise—it came from the teachers' union in Queensland. It said that we, the government, are taking money from the government schools and putting it into the non-government schools—no facts, no figures; it just makes the statement and then turns and runs.
I had to do some research to respond to that letter, and I was able to show quite clearly to the readers of the Toowoomba Chronicle, and hopefully to all at large, that in fact the federal government's funding commitment to government schools in Queensland has risen from $290 million per annum, when the coalition took office in 1996, to $385 million per annum now. Under this government, that figure is projected to reach $443 million in 2004. The federal government's $1.9 billion per annum commitment to state government schooling is rock solid and is part of our 4.2 per cent increase in education spending as outlined in our budget.  
I have had the pleasure in recent times of visiting a number of schools in my electorate. I picked up an imputation in the Leader of the Opposition's speech that the standard in government schools was declining, but I have not seen it. When I go to government schools, I see schools that are full of committed people. I see communities like the one at Fairview Heights, which I spoke of earlier, where the teachers are completely committed, and the standard is improving all the time. The outcomes that they are achieving there, with a combination of state and federal government funding, are outcomes we can all be proud of. I see a school in a new suburb taking on some of the teaching challenges that always present themselves in communities, and the use of mixed classes, where the older students assist the younger students as part of a process of helping those students who are having difficulty in learning, is something that I commend. As I said, I visit state schools regularly, and I have to say that I have seen no evidence at all of a slip in standards at government schools in my electorate. 
I guess that poses the question of why parents are moving from government schools to non-government schools. It is an issue of freedom of choice. After all, parents will always aspire to do what is best for their children, and that best does not always relate to the standard of education in terms of the three Rs. It can come from decisions relating to spiritual beliefs, discipline, whether or not they want their son or daughter to attend a same sex school, curriculum choice, parental involvement and even sporting opportunities. I do not in any way resile from the fact that the federal government will continue to assist government schools as we work to ensure that non-government schools are able to rebuild themselves from the catastrophe of funding that occurred under the previous Labor government. 
The suggestion that students in non-government schools come from rich parents is one which I despise intensely. In my electorate, where we have a number of poorer schools—all of which will benefit from this legislation—I am sure those parents will take equal offence at the comments from the Leader of the Opposition. It is interesting to look at the Bureau of Statistics figures which show that 21 per cent of school students in non-government schools come from families with an annual income of less than $26,000. It makes this statement about rich parents look pretty silly to me.
The government remains unruffled by these constant attacks coming forward from the Labor Party. The bottom line remains that there is simply no evidence of a move away from our commitment to government schools. On the issue of the EBA, which Labor like to try to run with, it is interesting to read some detail about how the states are reacting to the EBA and it is interesting also to note that the Ministerial Council on Employment, Education, Training And Youth Affairs acknowledges that the EBA's real purpose is about preventing cost shifting. What we are really trying to do with the EBA is to ensure that the state governments do not start pocketing the money which we are giving to them for the education of students who have moved into non-government schools which we then fund through another stream. The sort of thing that we regularly see—overlooked, though, by the Labor Party—is that in that formula we do not take back the total amount of the EBA; in fact, we only take half. Of course, it is another area that, when pressed, the state governments will acknowledge.
It is not just the federal government that wishes to see this legislation carried. Let me read from a letter that I received last week from the Australian Parents Council which says:
    The Bill recognises that every child is entitled to a base level of public funding for their school education. It provides a fairer way of giving parents at all income levels a chance of choosing the most appropriate schooling for their children. The Bill gives more equitable Commonwealth funding to non-government school students and is based on a more transparent measure of educational need. Commonwealth funding for non-government students and schools is linked to Average Government School Recurrent Cost (AGSRC). So it can be easily seen what proportion of public money as compared with the cost of government school education, is flowing to non-government school students. The proportion ranges from 13.7% to 70% of AGSRC.  
The letter finishes by saying that:
    The Bill guarantees security of Commonwealth funding for non-government schools—
something Labor never offered—
and students during the phasing in of the new funding mechanism. Commonwealth funding legislation for school education runs out at the end of this year.
And we need to see that legislation passed.
May I say that we really do need to see an end to the cheap politics being played out over children's education. This issue is far too important to allow the truth to be clouded by political gain. This issue is about ensuring that we have a fair, equitable and homogenous system which provides parents with choice—the choice of whether or not to send their children, who are far and away their biggest asset, to a government or non-government school. I reject absolutely the assertion that this government is cutting funding to government schools. I have seen no proof of it. I hear rhetoric, I hear partial quotes, I hear assertions, but I see no evidence. What I see is a federal government, as I said at the outset, committed to both government and non-government schools and to an education budget which continues to increase. It is very easy for the Leader of the Opposition to stand there and say: `We just need to spend more money on this and we just need to spend more money on that.' Of course, he has got form in that area. He spent a fair bit of money on everything when he was in charge of the purse strings—$12 billion, I think, was his best effort in terms of a budget deficit. He left us with an $80 billion deficit which we have had to deal with. Education funding is like all financial funding: it needs to be done concisely, transparently, fairly and sustainably. This bill does that, and I commend it to the House.

name: Sawford, Rod, MP
text:
—The member for Groom seems to think that, if you state an untruth often enough and loud enough, it becomes the truth. If ever two questions focused attention on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 2000, they were the two questions asked last Thursday by the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow minister for education, the member for Dobell. The Leader of the Opposition asked the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs the following question:
Minister, is it correct that funding for government schools can change for three reasons: firstly, automatic indexation for school cost increases and enrolment growth according to a formula set down by Labor in 1993; secondly, discretionary decisions to increase funding; and, thirdly, discretionary decisions to cut funding. Minister, is it correct that a senior official of the Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs told the Senate last week—
that is the previous week—
that the total of discretionary increases for government schools was $106.4 million over the next four years? Is it not also correct that your enrolment benchmark adjustment—
which we will abolish—
a discretionary cut, will take more than $150 million from government schools over the next four years? Minister, is it not true that the net effect of your policy decisions, as opposed to automatic increases, is to cut funding for government schools?
The minister's answer, of course, evaded the question. He stated contemptuously that an enrolment benchmark adjustment is not a school funding policy. What remarkable duplicity! What duplicitous denial! Yet this policy takes more than $150 million from government schools over the next four years while increasing funding by $106.4 million. 
To anyone else that is a decrease in funding to government schools. I have not heard one person say anything different, except the minister and the government backbench. I have not heard one person from the independent schools or Catholic schools or low-fee Christian schools defending this appalling EBA policy. The minister is alone with his backbench and his government on this matter. He ought to be soundly condemned and pressured into resignation unless he withdraws the discriminatory policy of enrolment benchmark adjustment against government schools. The only concession to the Leader of the Opposition's question was that government school enrolments would increase by 2.3 per cent; but that will have to be achieved with considerably less funding. 
The second question was asked by the shadow education minister, the member for Dobell. His question was:
Is the minister aware that a senior official of his department told the Senate inquiry into his new school funding formula that an extra $50 million to 62 category 1 schools was `probably a good estimate'? Is the minister also aware that his enrolment benchmark adjustment has already taken more than $60 million from government schools? Minister, how can you claim that your legislation is designed to restore equity and fairness to school funding, to use your words, when it takes $60 million from government schools and gives $50 million to the 62 wealthiest schools in Australia?
The minister, predictably, denied that this was the case. The minister explained that a reduction of $60 million from government schools—that is, the EBA—is described as a federal-state financial transaction. If that is not a funding arrangement, then I do not know what is. If that is not doublespeak in the dodgy language of the minister, then I do not know what is. It is illuminating that the minister's comments regarding the question completely failed to acknowledge the loss of funding to government schools. Why would anyone be surprised about that? The coalition's Expenditure Review Committee minutes prove that David Kemp has been on a 10-year crusade to drive students out of government schools. The member for Groom admitted that. The coalition's ERC minutes for 1991 record very clearly the intentions of the government. They state:
He—
that is, Dr Kemp—
noted that the coalition sought to encourage students to move from government to non-government schools.
Why would anyone be surprised? In the same minutes it was agreed that Dr Kemp would report back to the ERC on the subject of `non-government schools—whether additional expenditure could be offset by reductions in grants to government schools and untied grants'. Since the Howard government took office in 1996, Dr Kemp has systematically implemented every one of those plans by establishing in the enrolment benchmark adjustment policy—which I have already explained has taken $60 million from government schools and will take $150 million over the next four years—by cutting untied grants to the states by more than $1.5 billion in 1996, and by now massively biasing Commonwealth funding in favour of wealthy private schools.
The minister's claim of generosity, fairness and equity towards government schools is simply fraudulent. The increases to government schools are driven by an automatic indexation formula that has been in place since 1993. If Dr Kemp had given government schools any less, he would have had to pass a budget measure to cut their funding. Another point: why is this minister asking this House to pass this bill at this time—at a time, I remind all members, when the data collection about his funding model is not complete? In fact, this is unlikely to be completed until the end of September.
The opposition have already discovered the bias towards category 1 schools at the expense of government schools. What else in the fine print of this legislation also stinks? Over a year ago the shadow minister for education, the member for Dobell, asked the minister for the modelling showing the way in which the new system will distribute government funding to private schools. The shadow minister, surprisingly, received nothing. That private schools get public funding is not argued. Labor have always said we support extra funding for needy non-government schools and that we would support the new system if it were fairer. But how could anyone come to a conclusion that it would be fairer if the following takes place: the average category 1 school gets an extra $800,000 a year, the average Catholic school gets an extra $60,000 a year and the average government school gets an extra $4,000 a year? That is 200 times less. Is this what the minister means by raising education to a new level of fairness and equity? It this what the minister means by transferring funding from government schools, which 70 per cent of Australian children attend, to schools which 53 per cent of the cabinet attended—exclusive category 1 schools which cater for a small minority of privileged students? 
The minister has delayed this legislation by more than 15 months. He has deliberately hidden the real figures, the real statistics, the real level of funding—that is, per capita levels—and the levels of expenditure on schools as a percentage of GDP, the only reliable measure. The minister has accused the opposition of lying. If he is to do so effectively, he needs to answer the following questions. Exactly how much additional funding will go to each of the 62 category 1 schools? When will the minister release the final figures showing the increase for each and every school in Australia to let us make a comparison? Why should category 1 schools get bigger increases than private or public schools with greater needs? How can this House be expected to vote on a $22 billion bill without knowing that information? As the shadow minister has indicated, the passage of this bill ought to be adjourned until that information is available.
This minister has, until the last couple of days, argued the mantra of freedom of maximum choice. It does not mean that at all; it means according to the ability of people to pay. That is for whom freedom of choice is a viable option. As I said earlier, the minister has now introduced a new mantra. In fact it was last week when he had the gall to state that he intended to raise fairness and equity to a new level in Australia. And pigs might fly! This bill does nothing for disabled children. This bill does nothing for rural children. This bill does nothing for children in socioeconomically depressed areas. This is a great sadness because this government promised to govern for all Australians.
This government's action in education is a threat to our Australian democracy founded on the secular state, founded on non-discriminatory universal access to education, founded on widely shared knowledge, values and justice for all, and funded on equal education opportunity. That is what is really threatened, and that is a threat to all of us. It is not just the Labor opposition and the AEU saying this; many academics have spoken out about the direction this government has taken and the risk involved in pitting one group of Australians against another, of creating winners and losers in education opportunities. I have mentioned previously in this House the concerns of the Anglican Diocese of Melbourne, whose synod views with dismay the increasing polarisation between rich and poor in facilities and infrastructure provided within the government school system, exposing the more vulnerable sections of the community. They do not agree with the government's new schools policy either. Their report The state of our state schools, which was published in August 1998, states:
    In the interests of social cohesion it would be better that the proliferation of small, low-fee private schools (many with sectional interests) cease.
The Anglican Diocese of Melbourne obviously do not give any credence to the minister's mantra on choice either. Let me quote them again:
    The present emphasis on choice should be dropped. Competition between schools increases inequalities and exacerbates social division.
Areas of concern identified by the Anglican Diocese of Melbourne included the following: the decreased funding of government schools, the increased spending on non-government schools at the expense of government schools, and an education debate hampered by the difficulty in obtaining reliable information. That was not the Labor Party; that was not the AEU; that was not the government school sector. That was the Anglican Diocese of Melbourne—rightfully, responsibly, warning all Australians of the dangers inherent in current government policies in education. Thankfully, one responsible sector of Australian society, one not known for politicising issues, is not prepared to just look on while individualism replaces social concern and community development and the rules of the market prevail and undermine the development of community. I dare the minister and I dare any member on the government side to accuse the Anglican Diocese of Melbourne of lying as he does those of us in the Labor opposition.  
This government is taking Australian education down the very slippery slope of the single market that will certainly cause failure in both the public and the private system. Behind the government's rationale for this bill is the creation of a single market in education. On the worst interpretation, this government is deceitful and malevolent as far as education is concerned. On the best interpretation, it is simply incompetent and blissfully unaware of the dangers in which it places the future of Australian society.
This government believes in blurring the distinction between public and private schools. According to Associate Professor Alan Reid of the University of South Australia, the government's central strategy is the establishment of an education quasi-market. That view is essentially shared by the Anglican Diocese of Melbourne. That is, the government seeks to create a single market in education where all schools, public or private, compete for custom. Some people respond to that proposition of a single market by saying, `So what? Won't competition in the education market make for greater efficiency?' To those people, I would say this: education is not a simply described product that can be crudely measured—it is not a tube of toothpaste, it is not a loaf of bread, it is not an automobile and it is not the latest fashion accessory. 
If the logic of the creation of the single market by this government were followed, all government schools would be abolished, as a dollar spent on a private school could be argued to be more cost-effective. That is the line that the member for Groom used. The language of the single market, as used by this government, whether it be the minister, the Prime Minister or the 53 per cent of the cabinet who attended category 1 schools, is just plain wrong. A single market assumes all schools operate under similar circumstances. They do not. Private schools select students; public schools cannot. Schools that cater for children with social or economic disadvantage, behavioural disadvantage, intellectual disadvantage or physical disadvantage will never be catered for in a single market. I repeat: never in a single market.
The single market in education means the abandonment of these children. That very fact raises grave questions about the future integrity, cohesion and democracy of this nation. The marketisation of education values education only in financial terms. The intrinsic values of education—civics, responsibilities, justice—are simply ignored. This government does not appear to understand that encouraging competition between inadequately resourced schools will simply up the ante and result in increased alienation, resentment and anger. While markets obviously have an important role in our economic system, the rules of the market are simply insufficient for the government of a society.
Education is supposedly being marketised to increase efficiency, management expertise and freedom of maximum choice. What is actually happening is the deliberate reduction in real education expenditure and the devolution of responsibility to the schools themselves to reduce the political fallout for the government of the day. That some narrow sighted professional people within education departments and public schools—affluent areas, of course—support marketisation and devolution certainly muddies the water, but it does not make it right. This government is intent on setting citizens and their children into competition with each other so that there are winners and there are losers. As the Age editorial of 24 August stated: 
    Dr Kemp must move beyond the rhetoric about providing choice to students and their parents and comprehend his obligation to give all children an equal chance of fulfilling their potential. 
That, of course, is yet another example to make a mockery of the minister's claim that he is raising fairness and equity to a new level. I said earlier that at worst this government is malevolent about education and at best simply incompetent. Either way, the dangers to the future of democracy are real. A single market in education, I remind the House, is antidemocratic. To meet the needs of some in education at the expense of others is antidemocratic. To increase division, separation and stratification of society is antidemocratic. The weakening of national cohesion is a threat to our democracy. To support the private purposes of schools impairs the democratic purposes of schools. If private and economic purposes are allowed to be determinants of education, as this government allows, then proposals to extend democratic purpose cannot be achieved. I repeat: they cannot be achieved. However, if democracy is to be valued, everyone in this House must defend all to be included in education, and we must do so vigorously. 
This bill ought to have tackled a whole range of unsatisfactory issues—retention rates, gender imbalance, age profile of teachers, teacher training; locational disadvantage; socioeconomic disadvantage; the care of disabled children; early intervention; real literacy and numeracy skills backed up by social skills and technological skills; resource allocation according to need; differential funding rates; accountability of state governments in education; innovation and education; and reliable data with comparative longitudinal studies in education to remove the risk of so much guesswork in this country and bias in the future planning of education. But of course that would have meant integrity, fairness, equity, planning for the future, and preparing for change. Of course, that is anathema to this Prime Minister, this minister and this government.
I support the call that this debate be adjourned until all relevant information pertinent to this debate is available. This afternoon I received an interesting letter from ACSSO, the Australian Council of State School Organisations. I quote from the last page:
    One of the supporters of Dr Kemp's policies, Alan Mitchell, Economics Editor of the Australian Financial Review, let us in on what Dr Kemp's “reform” really means. He described them as promoting: “means-tested vouchers”, government schools with the “more flexible management structures of the private sector”, “publicly-owned and financed, but ...self-governing”, and “the public system more like the (expanding) private system.” He raised the possibility of means-tested funding of government schools.
Let us go to Victoria. The letter continues:
   Two other supporters of Coalition policies, Brian Caldwell (advisor to the Kennett Government) and Don Hayward (Kennett's first minister for Education), have estimated that if these market policies are followed, only around 30% of government schools will survive. What then happens to the guarantee of a free, high quality, secular education in a local government school?
The letter continues, saying that this government is driven by:
... ideological obsession with markets. The aim is to privatise provision, and to shift the costs of schooling onto parents. Around 70 % of Australian parents send their children to government schools, and public opinion polls show overwhelming public support for fully funded government schools. These policies are not supported by the Australian people—
that is, the policies of this government—
which is why the Coalition is trying to keep their real intent hidden.
Secret agendas, secret documents and placing the future of this nation and our children at risk are not something to be recommended to even this government. I would hope that some people on the government side, when they join this debate, will at least have the honesty to acknowledge what the minister and this government are attempting to the great disadvantage of all of us in this country. (Time expired)
