name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
text:
—Socioeconomic status is a key predictor of educational disadvantage, although there are of course interesting exceptions as shown by studies both here and overseas. Certain migrant groups from the lowest socioeconomic status groups, among which Asian families figure prominently, do not conform to such predictions. For example, a United States study found that 30 per cent of the children of Indochinese boat people scored better than 90 per cent of American students on mathematics and only slightly less well on language skills. Another fascinating United States study found an illuminating difference between attitudes to failure at school among Caucasian Americans, Chinese Americans and People's Republic of China nationals. The first group, the Caucasian Americans, attributed failure to bad luck or bad schooling. The second group, the Chinese Americans, attributed failure to lack of effort with some allowance for other variables, and the PRC Chinese overwhelmingly put failure down to lack of effort.
In Australia, some ethnic groups have notably outperformed Australian born students and this is even in cases where the IQ of individuals is lower and the socioeconomic status is also lower. One such group of high performers are the children of first generation immigrants of Greek peasant background with either little or no education at all. In all such cases, it seems that the key is the attitude to education held by the parents. Parents in these groups want their children to get the education they never got and they instil in their children an ideal of the value of education and of how it can be used to make a better life. Obversely, a major study in the US, the Coleman report, found that although black youths registered highly on the measure `interest in learning', their inability to imagine that any efforts of theirs could be successful meant that there was a negative correlation between years in schooling and achievement. You need to be able to imagine success before you can achieve it. The same poor Afro-Americans ascribed success more to luck than to effort. So there is a lot more to education outcomes than socioeconomic status alone but, despite the exceptions I have outlined, it has to be said that, sadly, where one is born and where one goes to school does seem to correlate with how one fares in the education system. A recent survey by the Australian Council of Educational Research found that students from poorer areas and those with less well-educated parents are opting for more vocational subjects in year 12.
This States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 2000 represents a sea change in funding arrangements for the school system, particularly for the growing non-government sector. It introduces new funding arrangements in the form of the SES, or socioeconomic status system, for non-government schools for the period 2001 to 2004. It is important to emphasise that this model is based on an independent assessment of the socioeconomic status of the school community and a vigorous and far-reaching consultation process with schools. The bill replaces a complex and outdated assessment of school resources, the Education Resource Index, known as the ERI. One of the problems with the ERI was that schools serving the same community could be funded at different levels under the category levels. Another was to do with disincentive. Schools wanting to raise extra funds through school fetes and the like could have their Commonwealth funding reduced in consequence. Schools were also locked into a funding level which determined their school community even if there had been fundamental changes in the socioeconomic status of that community. 
The ERI, it was also universally agreed, was enormously complex. It was transparent enough when it was first introduced but over the years had built up various layers of opacity, mainly the result of political decisions that had more to do with the electoral process than with logic or rationality. When it first started, there were eight categories, then there were six and then there were 12. Each time the number changed, there were changes to the formula. At one time it measured only expenditure on recurrent resources. It later measured recurrent resources but with a check on expenditure on capital. Then it assessed only income, and after that it checked it against expenditure as well. So ERI has been described as akin to tax law in its increasing complexity over the years. Both the ERI and the new SES have this in common: they assume that Commonwealth funding should be on the basis of needs. This is the continued assumption in the new system of funding: that schools should be financed in accordance with their level of need. This needs to be stressed because otherwise we could be led astray by the overwrought rhetoric of the opposition in this chamber.
The SES model which this bill introduces is the result of consultation with state and territory governments and with both the government and non-government school sectors. The terms of reference for the review of the ERI were circulated in the period from February through to April. After this there was a further round of consultations with the states and territories and, since the introduction of the bill, a national process of consultation across all jurisdictions across all states and territories and national peak bodies between July and August. The overwhelming response from schools to the review was that the ERI mechanism no longer accurately reflected need and did not allow schools to respond to the changing needs of their communities. This was particularly a problem for rural and regional communities throughout Australia. The strong point of the new SES system is that it allows funding along a continuum to reflect the capacity of a community to support a school.
What is also a key to understanding the new system and the reason for its coming into being is the government's belief that all students are entitled to a base level of public funding, regardless of the school which they attend. This means that schools on the highest SES score will have their minimum entitlement set at 13.7 per cent of average government school recurrent costs. The maximum Commonwealth entitlement for the neediest schools and for special schools will be set at 70 per cent of average government school recurrent costs. Increased funding for schools will be phased in over four years and the government has given an undertaking that no school will be financially disadvantaged in moving to the new funding system.
This bill has two important further provisions which are quite novel. The first of these is that schools will not be penalised for raising private income, in line with the government's belief that communities should not be discouraged from providing additional resources for their schools. The second change is that distance education students in non-government schools will become eligible for Commonwealth recurrent funding set at 13.7 per cent of the average government school recurrent costs. Distance education students in the government sector already benefit from this, and this measure gives parity to those in the non-government sector in similar circumstances.
This government takes seriously its responsibility for dealing with the continuing scandal of illiteracy and innumeracy in our schools. At the end of 11 years of Labor negligence of performance assessment in the schools, up to 30 per cent of our children were finishing school unable to read or write with any proficiency. As a result of this bill, literacy and numeracy benchmarks agreed to by Commonwealth and state ministers will be incorporated into regulation. Other performance measures will also be incorporated as they are agreed to by education ministers. This emphasis on accountability and measurement of performance is part of the sea change which the Howard government has brought about in how government deals with schooling. 
The opposition have made a meal out of objecting to any increase in funding for wealthy non-government schools. The points they fail to mention or to take into account in this debate are that, where schools do have high resource levels, that is due to the investment of after tax dollars in fees from parents, donations and sponsorships. This government does not believe in penalties for private investment in education. In any case, communities that have a high capacity for generating funds will be shown up in the SES index and, as a result, will get less public funding for the schools to which they send their children. The opposition have been throwing about a lot of erroneous figures about how much will be going to the most wealthy schools under the new funding arrangements. No individual school among the wealthiest 62 will be funded at an average level, as the Labor Party keeps saying. Some will receive funding at a higher level only because of the guarantee that funding will be maintained where otherwise it might have been reduced. This is to say that such wealthy schools receive that funding only because they were maintained at that level by Labor.
The Commonwealth government is increasing funding for government schools more rapidly than any state government in Australia. This is despite the fact that the states largely control funding for the government sector while the Commonwealth is responsible for the non-government sector. The Commonwealth will be spending $402 million more on government schools this year than in 1996, when the Labor Party legislated the amount of funding for government schools. This represents a 26 per cent increase by the Howard government for government schools over the past four years, yet the number of students in government schools has increased only by 2.3 per cent. Non-government organisations—Catholic and non-Catholic, independent and Christian schools—support this legislation. They see it as providing choice for working-class families.
The Catholic Education Commission have chosen to stay outside the SES system for their own reasons. They employ the SES to distribute funds within their system. The Catholic sector supports the government's legislation and has been urging the opposition to support this bill. Father Tom Doyle, Deputy Chair of the National Catholic Education Commission and Chair of the Victorian Catholic Education Commission, told the Senate committee that he:
... supports the [bill] ... and endorses the Commonwealth's application of the principle of need in making grants to Catholic systemically-funded schools.
This bill is about introducing fairness, equity and social justice into our schools funding. On this side, these concepts are more than just airy nothings. The Labor Party, for all their sound and fury, are supporting this bill. I think that speaks for itself. I commend the legislation to the House.
Sitting suspended from 6.23 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

name: Ellis, Annette, MP
text:
—I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 2000. But in doing so I must make the point that a Senate committee is currently inquiring into this legislation. I think it is reasonable to ask why we are debating the bill prior to the findings of that committee being released. It is a legitimate question; the government has yet to answer it in a convincing way. I make that note in passing.
This bill represents the formal legislation for Commonwealth funding for government and non-government schools for the period 2001-04. I understand it represents appropriation of around $18 billion or, in other words, $7.6 billion for government schools and $14 billion for non-government schools. Translated into percentage figures, 35 per cent of Commonwealth-only funding for schools is directed to government schools and 65 per cent is directed to non-government schools. The bill introduces a new method of per capita funding for non-government schools. This new method of funding for non-government schools means changing from the current education resources index, ERI, which assesses a school's total resource levels, to an index which measures the socioeconomic status, SES—occupation, education and income—of all of the parents who send their children to a particular school. The SES is based on the areas of data collection of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. While introducing this new funding formula, the government is also proposing to retain the enrolment benchmark adjustment policy, the EBA. 
I understand that the government conducted a simulation project in 1998 to test the theory of this new funding process. I believe that around 691 schools were involved. However, on the best available information, it seems that the simulation project threw up some interesting outcomes. At this point, I must say that not all of the details and not all of the figures are available from the government, and I must reflect upon my comments earlier in relation to the Senate committee inquiring into this legislation. It seems difficult and somewhat unacceptable for the House to be asked to consider such an incredibly important bill when a Senate inquiry is under way and when all of the figures have not yet been made available to people on this side of the House. One of the interesting outcomes of the simulation project was that three-quarters of the 691 schools involved were better off under the new system and would move to this new SES funding system. Another prediction is that the 63 wealthiest schools in Australia, presently category 1 schools, will receive some $46 million extra funding a year under this bill.
By contrast, I understand that no extra recurrent funding, other than indexation and enrolment adjustments, is provided for government schools. Also, the EBA, the enrolment benchmark adjustment process, will continue to apply. We in the Labor Party have already announced our intention to abolish the unfair EBA and to put back into government schools funding essential for their future—funding which the Howard government is planning to remove from them. The EBA has removed about $60 million from government schools in the past three years, despite the fact that those same schools have enrolled more than 26,000 extra students.
This debate is not class warfare, as the government would like everyone to believe purely on the basis of our objections; it is simply about fairness and equity. I personally do not object to it purely because some private schools seem to do well out of this funding mechanism; but I object, and I object strongly, when I see the funding formula take money from one sector and funnel that money into another sector. It is that inequity that I object to. It is simply not good enough, it is simply not acceptable, when we know that the 70 per cent of children who attend government schools will suffer as a consequence of this government's actions within this bill. The Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs has the front to stand in this place time and again, metaphorically with his hand on his heart, and say that funding to government schools has increased under his stewardship. This is simply not the case. I do not believe that either sector—the government school system or the non-government school system—wants to have this debate. The Prime Minister and his minister for education are creating a division between them by applying this retrograde policy through this bill. We will abolish the EBA—that is an absolutely unequivocal statement—and we will invest in an honest and appropriate education system for all of our children. 
An area within education which needs special consideration in this debate is that of students with disabilities. This is a constantly growing problem and a perfect example of where government attention ought to be focused. I recall a Howard government promise back in 1996 that an extra $16 million or so would go towards special education. I am not quite sure whether that was a core or a non-core promise. It must have been non-core because it disappeared, along with many other similar undertakings, between then and now. I believe this bill provides a modest increase in funding in this area for non-government schools, but it does not increase at all the overall level of funding for these students in government schools. In fact, I understand that students with disabilities attending government schools will see per capita funding decrease from $126 to $102 per year. With more than 32,000 of these students, that adds up to around $750,000 a year—a very disturbing outcome in anyone's language. How can anyone call that fair or just?  
 The question of students with disabilities has been in the media to a great degree in recent times, particularly with regard to some non-government schools which have been calling for increased funding to cover their obligations and their requirements when they have children with disabilities attending their schools. I would applaud their call, but I would also say that, in doing so, we must consider what is happening in the government sector as well. When you see a drop in the per capita funding for children with disabilities in government schools from $126 to $102 per year, you can only condemn any government which believes that that is a proper, appropriate, fair or just policy to apply to any student anywhere in this country. Any increase is good, but let us be honest about what is really required.
Unsurprisingly, this bill has become very contentious and has drawn many varied views from many commentators. It would also be fair to say in a very general sense that the private school sector would be more pleased with the outcome of this bill than would the government school sector. I would like to go over the figures produced, I understand, by DETYA, the department concerned, which indicate the following. The average category 1 school will get an extra $800,000 a year. The average Catholic school will get an extra $60,000 a year—that is, 12 times less. The average government school will get a real increase of around $4,000 a year—200 times less. I support fully any extra funding for needy non-government schools. I also believe very strongly in a healthy, fair and just dual system. But to have that fair, healthy and just system, we must ensure that the system is funded in a fair, healthy and just way. Taking dollars from one and funnelling them into another is not fair, just or healthy.
This country's future depends on a government investing in our education system in a proper way. Many of our trading partners are showing investment in education systems and their future that, frankly, put us to shame. Australia is the only country in the OECD where we see spending on education, training and research declining. And it is declining at a rate that no-one could applaud. This government and this minister are failing our children, are failing our future and are failing this country if they continue on this ideological bent. What we should be debating is forward thinking, progressive legislation with fair and just investment in the whole of our education system—legislation that offers hope and reward to every child participating in that education system throughout the country, regardless of their financial circumstances and regardless of where they live. Instead, we see this tawdry attempt at playing around the edges, shifting valuable resources in a crude political game and selling short our children and their educational potential.
What this minister should do is, one, abolish the inequitable and unfair EBA; two, reduce those funding increases for the ERI category 1 schools and redirect that funding to special education in both government and non-government schools; and, three, provide increases in federal funding for government schools to match the significant increases for non-government schools. This is not about trying to drive a wedge between particular sectors of this community. It is not about saying that, if you live in one area and you happen to have the right socio-economic reading from that area, you will get more or less, regardless entirely of what may be required in that area. What it is about is a government and a minister being honest, dropping the ideological cloak that at the moment is encompassing them and saying that the calls for a proper and fair approach to education in this country are correct. 
The figures show the decline in investment. The figures show that some areas are far better off than others. Frankly, the policies that we announced through our national conference recently, with both the priority zones for schools that need the help and the abolition of the EBA, were the first two most important steps that we could see. Rather than the government scoffing at these things, what they need to do is to re-examine very carefully where they actually sit on these issues and to make sure that, at the end of the day, they are going to be able to face up to the outcome of their decisions. The outcome of their decisions will be read by this community at large and will be measured and judged in exactly the same way as this government is approaching them.
In conclusion, I oppose entirely the whole thrust of this government in relation to their education funding policy. I am appalled by the fact that they wish to drive such wedges through our community. We are going back in a debate that was finished many years ago. I would encourage them to consider very carefully the judgment of their actions in the future because, frankly, I do not know very many people out there at all in the general community who are going to applaud the outcome of this bill as it stands.

name: McArthur, Stewart, MP
text:
—In March 1997 the Commonwealth, state and territory education ministers agreed to a national literacy goal, and that was that every child leaving primary school should be numerate and should be able to read, write and spell at an appropriate level. I draw the attention of the House to that as fundamentally a state problem. Both sides of the House would agree with that laudable objective that Australia's young children should have these skills when they leave the primary school level. The Commonwealth agreed at that conference to provide grants for fostering literacy and numeracy development, targeting the educationally disadvantaged students, and grants for national literacy and numeracy strategies and projects. So this government are committed to ensuring that Australia's young people in this modern age have the capacity and the ability to read and write at an advanced level for a western nation.
I am concerned that the debate in this parliament has been divided quite strongly on this States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 2000 and, fundamentally, on the funding of independent schools. The real argument is the matter of Australian parents and their children having a choice about whether they wish to attend an independent school and pay the necessary funding or, on the other hand, wish to attend a government funded school with no payment from the parents involved. In my assessment, that is a fundamental right of Australian parents. I think those sitting opposite agree with the fundamental position that, no matter what state or territory Australian parents come from, they are entitled to make the choice of school that they wish for their children. I draw to the attention of the House the fact that this government has provided an alternative choice of private health care. Again, those opposite got involved in a major argument about the ability of private health funds to provide this choice and the cost to Australian taxpayers. We see a situation in both health and education in this society where people have a choice and where the system is not dominated by government agencies. That is very much in the ethos of the Australian tradition: we have a choice, we make those decisions and on some occasions we make a contribution to that choice.
In my home state of Victoria, 31 per cent or thereabouts of students attend independent schools. So parents of almost one-third of students have made the choice and are prepared to pay the money so that their children might attend an independent school which is funded partly by the federal and state taxation system and also partly funded by the after-tax dollars of the parents. The parents have a choice of curriculum and of the quality of that curriculum; the quality of the teachers; the class size, either small or great depending on the economics of the school; the discipline which the school may apply, either good, fair or not so good; the ethos of the school, which can vary from institution to institution, as most of you would be aware; the academic standards that the school will apply to their students and staff; and the performance outcomes of those students. That is very important, and the independent schools and, to a degree, the state schools are in a competitive situation to ensure that their students are beating those quality outcome standards. Of course, a number of independent schools have a religious background. It is fundamental in Australia that independent religious organisations have the capacity to create a school of their choice.  
I would like to draw to the attention of the House in a calm and equitable manner—unlike some members opposite who have been a little bit excitable about this debate—what the shadow minister and others opposite have had to say about this debate. I agree with the shadow minister, the member for Dobell, when he says:
   Improving educational opportunities for every student at every school must be our goal.
That is the goal of those of us on this side of the parliament. In another part of his speech yesterday, he went on to say:
   Raising the standard of education and training in Australia does not just open up new career choices for young people who are at risk of dropping out or disconnecting from our society and it does not just open up better career choices for students; it also opens up new possibilities for our country.
We have no argument with that. We support the general philosophy. The shadow minister then talks about the situation in the United States where training of the teachers has shown a big improvement in recent times. I was fortunate enough to be in the United States in recent weeks. It was quite clear from the Governor of Florida, the brother of the candidate for the presidential elections, Jeb Bush, that training of teachers and their activities in schools in Florida were under considerable review. If a school did not get the desired outcome in year 1, they got more funding, in year 2 they got more funding if the schools were not up to standard; but in year 3 the parents of children at those schools have the right to take their children away. Even in America the standard of teachers is being looked at very carefully. I note that the second reading amendment moved by the shadow minister states:
... the distribution of funding among the non-government schools is profoundly unfair.
I refute that statement quite categorically, as I will go on to demonstrate. The member for Rankin made a sensible contribution and had this to say:
   In fact, in my view, there is a lot of merit in the concept underlying the funding formula introduced in the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill because that funding formula is based on an index of socioeconomic status. But the application in this legislation of the SES funding formula is flawed.
But he agrees with the basic concept and he has it on the record. At least he is applying it intelligently. I listened carefully to the contribution by the Leader of the Opposition. Again, that was a considered position. He has a long history in the education debate. Of course, his father introduced state aid during the time of the Whitlam government in 1973. I note that he is not opposed to funding going to independent schools. He has put on the record that he is not opposed to the funding.
—Do you believe it?
—It is interesting whether or not we believe it, but he said in a carefully prepared statement to this House that funding to independent schools should be on a needs basis. That is where we have a little bit of a problem in how we apply the original state aid argument which Kim Beazley Sr introduced in that historic legislation in 1973. The really fundamental question facing this parliament and this nation is how we apply taxpayers' dollars to the independent school sector, whether it should be needs based or on the parental capacity to pay. This government and the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs have brought about a fundamental change, with which some members on the other side of the parliament agree, that we need to look at the capacity of parents to make a payment in the independent school sector rather than establishing that schools have a certain amount of wealth—and I say the word `wealth' advisedly. 
A number of members opposite have made great play about certain independent schools being wealthy, but they have not acknowledged that a number of the parents paying the fees to these so-called wealthy schools are of middle income means, who pay their taxes and who make great sacrifices to send their children to a so-called wealthy school. I concede the point that some of the schools in category 1 do have facilities that have been built up over decades by parental support and by the hard work of previous generations, but the real difficulty in applying funding to independent schools is how to identify which of the categories a school should be in. As all speakers in this debate would be aware, the categories range from category 1, regarded to be the wealthier schools, to category 12, regarded to be the schools with poor facilities and low parental income. Although it has been conceded on both sides of the debate that those two categories are self-evident, there are some anomalies in those areas. I draw to the attention of the House the great difficulty the administrators have in identifying which category certain schools might fit into—whether they should be in category 3, category 7 or category 8. The differences between those categories are brought about by some strange arithmetic calculations and historical data, which I think the administrators of the departments have great difficulty understanding themselves.
It is interesting to compare schools in my own electorate in the Geelong region. A school in category 10 has fees ranging from $1,600 to $1,800. In a category 1 school, the fees range from $6,000 to $10,000. The difference between the category 10 schools and the middle category schools—those between category 3 and category 6—is $3,500 to $7,500 depending on the category the administrators put those schools into. I have had considerable representations from schools in my area that this system is unfair and that arbitrary judgments by administrators, putting schools into particular categories, do not deliver reasonable outcomes for those parents. Those parents pay their taxes and they pay the school fees with after-tax income, yet by an arbitrary movement by the department here in Canberra, based on historical data, schools can end up in a category that I think all fair-minded people would question. So the minister and the government have come up with a new system and funding formula which we on this side of the parliament advocate is fairer to the parents. I think even the Leader of the Opposition would concede that the category system has some flaws. The opposition were unable to provide an alternative system when they were in government. 
It is interesting to observe that, in the Australian system, parents provide about 45 per cent of the total funding for non-government schools. In rough terms, parents provide about half the funding to their private schools, the Commonwealth provides about 37 per cent and the states provide 18 per cent. In very round terms, the parents provide half the funding and the Commonwealth and the state, out of taxpayers' money, provide the rest.
In providing a new regime for independent schools, the coalition abolished Labor's new schools policy, a policy which fundamentally stopped the establishment of any new non-government schools. That allowed a genuinely competitive situation and gave choice to parents in rural, regional and urban Australia. If you talk to independent schools, they are bemused by the complex ERI—the education resources index—process and have difficulty understanding it. In many ways it is inequitable because schools serving the same community, as is the case in the Corangamite electorate, can be funded quite differently. Those figures I quoted a moment ago demonstrate that point. The ERI is inflexible because the schools tend to be locked into a funding category, and they are unable to move up or down depending on changes in circumstances. 
The other key feature is that independent schools that make an effort to raise funds in a capital sense are discouraged because of their category. The proposition the government is putting forward, after considerable research, is the SES—the socioeconomic status of the school community. This transparent methodology was developed by Melbourne University, the data being available from the reliable census figures. The SES methodology is fair and is related to parents' capacity to pay. The SES methodology is flexible, so schools can move according to their background parental capacities. The SES methodology removes the disincentives to private investment and provides the private sector with the choice to raise more money to improve the possibilities of that school both in an educational and a capital sense. Surely in the interests of the whole of Australia that is a step in the right direction. The SES is a simple process.
For the interest of members—the process has not been debated in the parliament—the students' addresses, not the names of the students, are taken from the ABS collection and an index developed. Fundamentally, if the SES score is over 130, the school will receive the base entitlement they are now receiving. All schools with an SES score of 85 or below will receive maximum funding and those schools in between will get an ongoing entitlement, depending on where they sit in the program. The funding is based on the average government school recurrent costs. It is based on the government school arrangements where that is a genuine costing. Those opposite cannot really complain too much about that.
In the remaining minutes, I mention that it was interesting to receive two letters from proponents of, and those against, the arguments. The Australian Parents Council has written a letter to all members. I think they understand the argument that this bill recognises that every child is entitled to a base level of public funding. They say in the second dot point in their letter that the bill is based on `a more transparent measure of educational need', rather than on the old one to 12 situation. They say that funding relates to `Average Government School Recurrent Cost', something that I have mentioned, and that `this proportion ranges from 13.7 percent to 70 per cent of the government cost'—again, a fair and equitable system that everyone can understand. They further say that this bill `guarantees security of Commonwealth funding for non-government schools' in the new funding arrangements.
We also have a letter from the Australian Education Union. In all fairness, I looked at it very carefully to see whether it proposes a sensible argument against the proposition that the government has put forward. After viewing the letter, I really cannot see a sensible argument. They say `simply don't blame state governments' for any difficulties in the education system. Fundamentally, the state governments run the primary and secondary education system and we give some assistance to them by way of grants, but we assist the independent sector. So I do not think that the Australian Education Union really has a good argument.
I will just summarise the position as I see it in this very seminal and important debate on education in Australia: the new funding model is about parents, students and educational choice—matters I have raised before. It is not about government school versus non-government school, which so many members opposite have put in their arguments time after time. Every child in Australia is entitled to support from the government for their education, whether for a total amount or a smaller amount to independent schools. The new funding for non-government schools will not lead to a reduction in government school funding. The minister and the government have made it quite clear that they will increase the total amount of federal funding for schools in their area of responsibility. The new funding model uses objective data about the needs of school communities to redress the past inequities and to fund schools in similar circumstances in similar ways. That summarises the position quite simply. 
Parents who invest their after tax savings in their children's education contribute to the national investment in education, and that is a desirable outcome. Parents using non-government schools in Victoria save Victorian taxpayers $650 million. That is a desirable outcome from the Victorian taxpayers' point of view. For every dollar of taxpayers' funds that state and federal governments spend on government schools, only 25 per cent is spent on non-government schools. That is a very important fundamental statistic that those opposite have tended to complicate and argue against. I strongly advocate the new system as being fair and reasonable. I hope those opposite will support the bill in the Senate, that the Democrats will support the bill and that there will be a new era of fairness and equity in independent schools funding. (Time expired)
debate_title: <title>STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) BILL 2000</title>

name: Irwin, Julia, MP
text:
—I rise to make a contribution to this debate on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 2000. The Labor Party has a special interest in education. We see it as our future. The government sees education only in terms of another avenue to advantage their friends or advance the privatisation agenda. The Labor Party believes in equal opportunity. We do not believe privilege should decide whether you get a good education. We do not believe you should be able to buy education. What the government means by choice is not what everybody else means by choice. It is restricted to those with the ability to pay. I am concerned, representing an electorate that overwhelmingly uses the public school system, with the statement of intent by the minister that he is actively wanting a shift from the public school system to the private school system. That was recorded in the coalition ERC minutes of 1991. I will read from those minutes where it says:
It was agreed that Dr Kemp would report back to the committee on non-government schools whether additional expenditure could be offset by reductions in grants to government schools and in untied grants.
Well, he has. And this is what we have today: the complete opposite of what the minister stated publicly on Meet the Press. It was raised by the shadow minister during question time last week. The minister's response was:
Get real.
The House will recall that he was invited by the Speaker to more adequately respond. He said that he had not completed his answer and again said:
Get real.
That was the extent of it. The Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs is telling the shadow minister for education that it is okay to say one thing in private and another in public. He did that in relation to universities when he said that the government had `no plans to charge commercial rates on university education'. What did he do? He put forward a nasty proposal to limit university education to paying students, paying $100,000. This is what the minister means when he says `get real'. We are real. We do not need to `get' it in that 1960s sense of the word. Where the minister is unreal is in expecting the public education system to provide a decent standard of education when it is being white-anted by incentives provided by the government for parents to exercise their so-called choice and send their children to privately run, fee charging schools. It is unreal to expect every family to be able to do that. That is the first point. 
—Where did you send your kids?
—I can see that I am upsetting the parliamentary secretary at the table. My children actually went to public schools. It is unreal for the public schools to be expected to deliver a reasonable standard of teaching when their school populations are reduced to those who have been kicked out of the private school sector and those from less well-off circumstances whose parents do not have any choice. That is the second point. It is unreal to believe that the EBA has any effect other than to reduce the capacity of the public school system to provide any sort of quality in education. They are turning into adolescent-minding centres so that the youth allowance can be paid to teenagers who really do not want to be there. They are being forced to time-serve with inadequately resourced teachers who do not have the time to help these young people to plan their vocational avenues, to sort them out and to guide them away from wasting their lives after they leave school.
 These students have to attend classes as if they have every intention of completing the higher school certificate. It leads to problems for other students who do have every intention of doing as well as they can at those difficult final exams. It takes teaching away from teachers. That is the most important point. This government is intent on making government schools fail. Exclusive schools are just that. They can exclude those students they do not want. They can dump the ones they do not want back into the public schools, and that includes the underachievers and those with limited literacy skills. 
Public education is certainly a challenge. We have got laws that compel parents to send their kids to school. We talk about universal education and the minister talks about quality education, yet Commonwealth funding for government schools through the EBA has cut $60 million out of that system over the last three years. Principals and staff put their hearts into building a school, then another school opens up nearby. If it is a category 11 school, the public school may lose students. When the Commonwealth is actively bankrolling privately run schools in competition with public schools, planning for educational needs in the public system becomes very difficult. The minister sees this as market forces at work, offering choice to consumers. In fact, it is creating a chaotic situation where the outcomes are not predictable and the disadvantage is all on the public school side. 
School councils are writing to me saying they are concerned about the decline in public education while private education appears to be advancing. They look to the resources they have and they compare them with the new buildings springing up as non-government and privately run schools, thanks to the Commonwealth government. What they are observing are the effects of the government's redirection of funding from government schools to a competitive, private model in the guise of choice. The government is privatising education by putting the crunch on public education. It is transferring the cost as quickly as possible with this legislation. Dr Kemp calls it reforming the government school system, but it is wrecking the government school system, and it will mean lower income families and disadvantaged families will be left to spiral downwards. Their kids will be in an educational desert, and the more disadvantaged the family, the greater the desert.
It happened in New Zealand in the name of choice, but it is really unregulated competition. We have the same before us. Disadvantaged kids were the losers there and the educational outcomes produced greater inequality. Maori communities were the hardest hit. If we adopt this sort of public squalor/private wealth muddle here, we are not going to break the cycle of generational disadvantage; we are going to entrench it.  
The SES model is an attempt by this government to look after its landed constituency. We in the Labor Party believe in a needs based system. If you are on the land and you have a modest income, fine. If you are on the land with a good income but you are surrounded by people of modest income, this SES arrangement determines that you are poor. The government admits that this is so in the arrangements it has to make for remote Aboriginal settlements which are situated, say, near a major mining town. If you have the means, says the government, we will not stand in the way of a substantial donation to the school. This is very interesting. Richard Pratt's $1 million cheque last year to the minister's old school, Scotch College, should not affect how much the taxpayers put into Scotch College. It is only the school showing a bit of enterprise. The public schools should learn from places like Scotch College and their adulterous but generous benefactors. 
The old system, the ERI arrangement, stood in the way of those sorts of donations. Non-government and private schools were, under the estimate, discouraged from getting out and doing a bit of good, old-fashioned fundraising. The government wants to get rid of the disincentives to private investment in education. Private and corporate sponsorship are uncapped. They want to transfer the cost of education away from the public sector and give non-government schools unlimited exercise over their expenditure—with almost double the Commonwealth assistance to the wealthiest private schools to help them along.
Social security payments are subject to an assets and income test—a means test. If you have the means, you do not qualify for government assistance. That is what the ERI measured: the means of those schools outside the government system seeking government assistance, and some of them sure had means. They had money and the full range of professional services—accountants and lawyers—to help them with their books. The best a poor public school P&C can come up with is willing hands and wonderful heart.
Knox Grammar can expect maybe an extra $1.3 million a year out of this legislation. Why is that? Why will the 62 top schools in the country get an additional $50 million a year out of this legislation? Why are taxpayers in my electorate being told they will have to pay for rich kids at elite schools with funds taken from their own basic and often deteriorating schools? And those elite schools will be free to increase their fees without any impact on the level of government support they get. The status of a private school is too frequently measured by the fees. This legislation will entrench fees over performance, facilities over excellence, class over equality, and new money over old money: the rich and tasteless. 
Dr Kemp has a strange and pessimistic vision of the future. He wants to entrench and fortify privilege. Kim Beazley, on the other hand, sees the future as an exciting time, rich with opportunities; but only if we invest in education now, for everyone. Times have been changing over the past 20 or 30 years. Migrants are most likely to be the Australian citizens with a greater commitment to their obligations and responsibilities than those still looking to the Queen. Those who came to settle here have had kids, and some of those kids who were born here have had kids. Life has moved along. The more recent arrivals, particularly among those from South-East Asia, actually value education. Their children quite freely acknowledge that they are working hard at their studies because their parents put so much into their future. It is not true of everyone, but it is true enough when parents have had to flee death and danger. 
Migrants do it tough here. They have to deal with the language barrier; they work hard to scrape the dough together and they live at the low cost end—all to give their children the full benefits of the opportunities they see. A lot of the children are bright, but the families do not have the resources to have them in private education. Whatever the so-called encouragement is, they simply do not have the money. They are people who have had a huge set-back. It is called `war'. Many had their studies interrupted before coming to Australia where they then had to take any job they could, learn the language, drive taxis, work night shifts, resume studies in English while dog-tired from work and, because time has moved on, start a family. 
Australia used to harbour prejudices against Europeans because they worked hard. Con the fruit man would have his kids working for him too, and the milk bar would be open seven days a week. I am pleased to report the work ethic is alive and well in my electorate of Fowler. I wish 1 could say the same about access to migrant English classes. In the last budget, $20 million was pulled from the Advanced English for Migrants Program. Why do we want to have immigration if it is only to condemn immigrants to be the working poor because they lack English skills? We are overlooking people with talent and skills—people who can contribute to their adopted country. They are resources we cannot ignore. They are mothers and fathers of children who will make us the knowledge nation. We can all share in a bright and prosperous future.
I can see the potential every time one of my local schools comes to visit Canberra, which is less than a few hours bus time away. The electorate has people of many different backgrounds and the kids reflect that. I have not come across a teacher who has not said something very positive about their students. Research shows a strong relationship between school disadvantage and educational assessment. Fowler, in Sydney's south-west, does not score too well in the wealth stakes overall, but the teachers there think the kids are terrific because they are keen to learn—maybe it is to do with mum's and dad's attitude; it certainly is not to do with socioeconomic disadvantage. My electorate had three students awarded the Australian Students Prize last year for achieving higher school certificate results—a wonderful effort—in the top 500 nationally. Their parents came from Cambodia, Laos and Vietnam.
Education should not be about redistributing resources to the top end of society. Education should be where equal opportunity means something, not just for the students or their prospective incomes. Oh no, we need brains to seize the opportunities Kim Beazley sees ahead. And, in the most Aussie way, we should not care whether the student is the child of a shop owner living above a shop in downtown Cabramatta and attending Canley Heights High School or is a student at Abbotsleigh. We will take both of them. They are our future, so long as they do not go offshore because of the lousy level of research grants and postgraduate openings this government is offering.
There were scientists demonstrating outside Parliament House last week. They were not your average workers. These were brain workers. Dr Kemp should have gone out there and talked to them. If we are going to get the brightest people looking after our country's future, we need to focus on where they live. We need to lift those areas where they are starting from behind. We need priority education zones where bright kids get a chance to do something for the nation, instead of ending up unhappy, with an incomplete education and a job that does not exploit their full potential. It is a wicked waste that directly threatens our and their future and guarantees a return to the class system, the social unrest it promotes and the cost it takes to maintain it.
These are good reasons to resist this new formula. They are reasons of self-interest. I would have thought the government would be comfortable with self-interest as a philosophy, but this legislation takes self-interest in its narrowest meaning. Only the few, under this legislation, will be able to get their hands in the till, and they will not be grateful. To them, it is only okay to get a government handout if it is by devious accounting or avoidance of one's financial commitments to the revenue. To them, people who get the dole are a lower form of life. But there is no difference: tax avoidance is the same as dole fraud, except tax avoidance is the easier of the two. They are both rorts, and so is this legislation. The wealthy schools have welcomed the SES approach. The wealthy schools have seen the simulation figures. They have had them for the past two years and are in a good position to make the judgement that the SES makes the sound of money sweeter. 
The department knows the figures. The minister knows the figures. The parliament does not know the figures. We are told we will see something some time this month, and here we are debating legislation in this House without knowing the full impact of the changes. No wonder this legislation has been mysteriously held up, delayed and concealed. It has been done without consultation with the New South Wales Department of Education and Training—which is a stakeholder, a very major stakeholder, because the department complements the funding provided by the Commonwealth to non-government schools and provides the public transport and other infrastructure for students whose parents are exercising choice in where they send their student son or daughter. 
In the suburbs around Liverpool there is a great range of incomes. There are quite large houses in the estates often right beside extensive housing department developments. Getting a profile of one's family lifestyle by using census data for a collection district is an appalling misuse of statistical information. It is certainly not one I would use in campaign planning. The ABS warn against the sorts of assumptions you can make from the survey areas they can prepare for you, and most of that work is for commercial purposes—businesses looking at their markets.
There were a number of models considered in the schools funding consultation report. The SES model was just one of them. We on this side supported needs based funding, but the SES method looks like having some rough edges to it that the government does not want us to look at too closely. The enthusiasm of the wealthier schools leaves one to wonder if we are going to be spending this $22 billion of taxpayers' money wisely. As I said at the beginning, the Labor Party has a special commitment to education because the nature of work is changing. The government has not understood that, unless we set the goal of being a knowledge nation, we will be trashed by those economies that have embraced it. (Time expired)
debate_title: <title>STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) BILL 2000</title>

name: Hall, Jill, MP
text:
—Education is the key to success both within Australia and on the world stage. It is the key that unlocks the door to knowledge, success, choice and a bright future. If as a nation we do not make a commitment to education and a commitment to quality education for all Australians—not just the few Australians that can afford to attend the exclusive private schools, the 62 category 1 schools many ministers and members of the government attended—then we as a nation are in real trouble. Education is something that is for everyone. Education is something that is a priority for a nation such as Australia.
In Shortland, the electorate that I represent—in actual fact, in the whole of Newcastle—there is not one category 1 school. So how is this increase in funding of nearly $50 million to 62 schools relevant to the people that live in the Newcastle area? It is not very relevant at all. It shows just where this government's priorities stand. 
This 1950s style government is led by a Prime Minister that sits in his Chesterfield chair, dreaming of the past and seeking to take Australia back to that era—an era where if your mother and father had an education, then you could aspire to a university education. But if your mother and father were ordinary blue-collar workers, working hard just to survive, then you were expected to follow them. The idea was that you had your place in life and that is where you stayed. If you were very lucky, then you could aspire to attend a technical college and maybe end up with a trade. But you must never, ever try to move out of your station in life. This is the vision that our Prime Minister, the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs and the members on the other side of this House have for Australia.  
This government has a distorted, outdated view of the world and the type of society we should live in. It is a view that is built on privilege and a belief that there should be a privileged class. The people that should form that privileged class are the government, the friends of the government and all the `right type' of people—those with money, those that have money now, those with education, those that have education now, those that have property, those that own great wealth and those in big business—and friends like Kerry Packer who gambles more money in one night than most people see in a lifetime. 
This government supports and believes in a culture of privilege and elitism, and nowhere is this more visible than in education where this government demonstrates its philosophy. Nothing can be a greater determinant of wealth and opportunity in life than education. What this government is seeking to do through this SES model is to ensure that only those from a privileged background are able to obtain that education. Study after study has shown that a person's educational level determines their income level, which in turn determines their life opportunities and all the choices they have in life.
This government wants to keep that education in the hands of a very few people, those people that can afford to go to wealthy schools. This government has attacked the public education system in every way and has actually made an art of being able to attack public education. It sees the system as something to be applauded and pursued with a passion. That is the way the ideologues on the other side of the House see it. You only enter the public education system if you cannot afford anything better. It is not a real choice. We really should not do too much to support people who go to private schools. 
 Since the Howard government was elected in 1996, it has embarked on a 10-year campaign of undermining public education. There have been massive cuts to universities—$1 billion out of our universities. Research and development money to universities has gone. There are plans to charge $100,000 to do a degree. What ordinary Australian children coming from ordinary working-class families can afford to pay $100,000 for a degree? I certainly could not have afforded to do that. I could not have afforded to pay that for my children to go to university. What this does is really put university education in the hands of an elite few. There is talk about bringing in vouchers for education. The government wants to replace HECS with real interest rate loans. This is a disgrace. The government has slashed funds to TAFE; it has devised a plan to privatise education in Australia. 
We know this is a government that believes in selling everything off. It has sold Telstra. It is pushing Australia down the privatisation road all the time. But surely you have to draw the line somewhere. Surely education is something that it is the role of government to provide. This government sees it as something that it brokers out to its friends in the private sector. Those that can afford it will get the quality education.
The Commonwealth funding is now being massively biased in favour of the wealthy schools—the schools that the members of this House who sit on the other side of this chamber went to. A majority of them went there. I find myself asking why any government would be so stupid as to jeopardise our future. I can only come up with one answer. That is that they are zealots. And the two head zealots are the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs and the Prime Minister, who are driven by an ideological obsession with the market. This government has pursued the privatisation of Australia's education system with zeal, and it is leading Australian society down the road to a future of lost opportunity and division, a society of haves and have-nots, where there are people living in absolute luxury, people that can have anything they want, whilst on the other hand there are people living from day to day, people that are having to approach charities for handouts, people that work hard and just cannot survive. This is a very sad picture in a country like Australia. 
What this government is doing is entrenching the trends of the past where the children of professional parents were twice as likely as children of unskilled parents to go to university or even complete year 12. This is what it believes our society should be like—that it should be not your ability that determines what level of education you get but rather the family finances. I find myself looking at a number of decisions that are taken, particularly in education, and I feel as though it is a revival of the old feudal system. When I was at university, I looked at the natural order of things. It was put that there is God in the centre, then the nobles. I think that members on the other side of this House see themselves as the nobles. Then there is the middle class, who can aspire and have some money. Finally, you have got the workers. And the workers stay there; they must never look to change their position in life. I think the government sees us as ants and bees where you have the workers and the drones, and that is where they always stay. The queen is at the top. The government's vision of society is not of a modern, 21st century society. It is not an inclusive society. If it were an inclusive society, the government would understand that the wealth of the country should be shared by all. Education should be shared by all. Without sharing education, you cannot share wealth. 
The ministers and our Prime Minister argue that by giving an extra $50 million a year to category 1 schools they are giving students and their parents choice. I ask the minister and the Prime Minister what choice they are giving a family that is struggling to put bread on the table. What choice will they have to go to, say, Scotch College, which has been given quite an airing here in the parliament? Where will they find the fees to pay for that? It is no choice. What the government is doing is taking money that would have been going into a school that they could actually afford to send their children to—the good local public school. What it is doing is taking money and resources away from those schools. What it is doing is ensuring that the public school down the road will not have a computer in it, will not have the same sporting equipment that the rich, category 1 private schools have. I find it absolutely despicable.
The bonanza the government has delivered to the category 1 schools may lead to a school like Melbourne's Wesley College reducing its $11,000 a year fees by $200. That will not benefit ordinary Australians and their children and it certainly will not benefit the people of Newcastle and Central Coast, the people that I represent here in this parliament. When we look at the members of the Howard ministry and where they went to school, we get some understanding of why they are giving category 1 private schools this extra $50 million. John Anderson went to the Kings School, Parramatta. The fees are $11,595. I know there are not too many families in Shortland that could afford that. Peter Costello went to Carey Baptist Grammar, Alexander Downer to Geelong Grammar, Robert Hill and David Kemp to Scotch College, Nick Minchin to Knox Grammar, Jocelyn Newman to Presbyterian Ladies College in Melbourne, Peter Reith to Brighton Grammar School, and Michael Wooldridge to Scotch College—Scotch College yet again!
Well, well, well! It is no wonder that we are here today giving extra money to those category 1 private schools. We are not about delivering quality education to all those kids that live in the south-west of Sydney, the west of Sydney, the Hunter; we are about making sure that those with money, those that come from a privileged background get the absolute, ultimate best!
We in the opposition support giving more funding to needy Catholic schools and independent schools. We are not opposed to that. But what we are really opposed to is the subsidising of wealthy schools, particularly when that subsidisation is at the expense of public schools, at the expense of ordinary Australian children. What it is doing is taking away their opportunity to gain an education. The government's SES does not take into account the resources that schools have either. I was absolutely disgusted when I read in the newspaper that donations and gifts to schools such as Richard Pratt's $1 million cheque to Scotch College last year will be ignored. The resources of the schools are totally ignored. These category 1 schools can get as many donations as they like, they can have as much money in the bank as they like, yet the government is still going to roll out this $50 million to the 62 most wealthy schools in Australia. I find that despicable, unacceptable and un-Australian. This government has a belief that it must redistribute wealth by taking it from those people in the most need and giving it to those in the least need. In other words, it thinks that those people that are poor and struggling or just making ends meet should take money from their pockets and give it to their wealthy friends. 
With this legislation we see examples of how millionaires who live in rural areas will be classified as poor if the postcode fits. Most of us live in areas where there is a mix of income levels and some areas are wealthier than others. But if an area has a substantial amount of people that earn a low income then the wealthy people will still have the education of their children subsidised. It is just not good enough. 
The Howard government's privatisation of our education system will have a devastating effect on the future of our children. This government is lowering the expectation of those Australian students whose parents cannot afford to send their children to school. This is really going back to the 1950s. I was talking to a young indigenous student recently who went along to a conference with other indigenous students. This indigenous student was horrified because she said, `Oh, when I finish year 12, I want to go to university,' and other indigenous students were saying, `Yes, I'd like to go to university too.' But the people that were in charge of this conference were saying, `Well, now, dear, maybe you shouldn't be thinking about going to university. Maybe you should look towards TAFE.' It is more of this stereotyping and putting people into little boxes. The little box areas—indigenous Australians, young Aboriginal people—should not be looking to university! Rather, if they are lucky, they may make it to technical college or TAFE!
This is a government of the 1950s, one that stereotypes all Australian students and Australians, one that has values reminiscent of the past and a destructive agenda, and one that robs students of opportunity. This is a government that is ensuring that only those with money have an education. It is elite. It has an elite approach to education and it wants to ensure that its friends are the elite of our society, that its friends are the ones that get to share the wealth. The Labor opposition do not accept this. We believe that all Australians should be given the opportunity to have a quality education. We believe that to deny bright young Australian students the opportunity to attend university is despicable.
The EBA should be abolished. We should restore funding to disabled students. Educational priority zones will be among things that the Labor Party will do, things that will really improve education in this country. The nations with educated, skilled work forces are the nations that will thrive. All Australians deserve a quality education. Your level of education should be determined by your ability, not your parents' income. If this government continues to privatise our education system, the system that 70 per cent of all Australian students attend, Australia will be the loser.
debate_title: <title>STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) BILL 2000</title>

name: Murphy, John, MP
text:
—I have just been listening to the member for Shortland giving her perspective on the implications for her electorate of this States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 2000. I would like to give my perspective on the implications of this bill for my electorate of Lowe. This bill has provoked quite a deal of controversy throughout Australia. The party I belong to, the Australian Labor Party, has opposed the material parts of this legislation, alongside sectors of the Australian polity—namely, the states, the Australian Democrats, the Australian Education Union and the Australian Council of State School Organisations. I note that the opposition to this bill has not been uniform, nor has it been unified. That being said, there are some common themes which I am compelled to raise tonight, issues going to the divisive nature of the legislation. 
 Firstly, there is the issue of the balance of the financial allocation to schools. The allegation is made, with justification, that private schools get more and the state schools get less. The electorate of Lowe is truly a microcosm of the primary and secondary school system. Lowe has it all: we have a strong representation of category 1 private schools at both primary and secondary levels, we also have a very wide range of state schools which have a relatively strong asset and income means, and parts of the electorate have poor state and non-government schools. Lowe is a microcosm of Australian society. The bill we are discussing tonight is going to affect every corner of my electorate. It is of the highest importance therefore to accept that this bill will achieve winners and losers as a direct consequence of the changes being made. I have visited many schools in my electorate. I have seen one state school struggle for over 11 years just to obtain a new school hall. Another struggled to get proper funding to upgrade the children's toilet facilities. My electorate has some of the richest and some of the poorest schools in the state of New South Wales.
This bill provides major amendments to the existing State Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1996. Perhaps the most significant amendment in this bill is the abolition of the assessment method by the education resources index or ERI. The new system has an alternative method of funding called the socioeconomic status model, or SES, and is based on the socioeconomic status of school communities, as the Bills Digest notes, to `reflect the capacity of a school community to support its school'. The BillsDigest further defines the SES as an index calculated from Australian Bureau of Statistics data which links the students' home addresses with their ABS collection districts. A score is allocated for each school. The lower the SES score, the less likely that school will be able to support itself, hence the more money it will get. According to the calculations provided, no school funding is supposed to fall as a result of these changes. The highest scoring schools will still purportedly get a 1.7 per cent increase in funding whilst the lowest scoring schools will get an estimated 14 per cent increase from their current ERI level of funding. As for government schools, the government has committed itself to an increase in funding of $1 billion over the next quadrennium. In fact, this is a compounded total increase over the next four years.
Essentially, the proposals contained in this bill ensure that all non-government schools funding increases, but by differing amounts. The truth is that there are both government and non-government schools in my electorate which need funding, and this bill should afford welcome relief to those schools. Both are in need of real increases in funding. Both are looking to these amendments as a means of improving the funding of schools and achieving the standards of education we all wish to see in our communities. But let us not be duped by the complicity of this government to veil its proposed new system under a banner of equity in education. The Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs in his second reading speech at page 2 stated:
Under the new arrangements general recurrent funding will be distributed according to the need and schools serving the neediest communities will receive the greatest financial support. This means that parents at all income levels will now have a realistic capacity to choose the most appropriate schooling of their child. 
What a comedy of errors in reasoning! We really need to dissect this statement and look at each mistake separately. First, the minister is asserting that the new arrangements will distribute the funds according to the need of schools serving the neediest communities. This premise is simply false. It is false because it is a fact that all non-government schools will enjoy an increase in funding. Under the new SES system, all non-government schools receive a minimum payment of 13.7 per cent of the average government school recurrent costs. By definition, not all non-government schools are schools `serving the neediest communities'. The conclusion is also false, but for different reasons. Simply, the minister cannot conclude that `parents at all income levels will now have a realistic capacity to choose the most appropriate schooling for their child'. If ever there were a case of an invalid conclusion based on a false premise, it is to be found here. The argument is wrong as well, basing the conclusion on a non-existent link with the premise. Put simply, what has the SES regime got to do with a parent's capacity to pay? Does the minister really believe that, by assessing a school's payments requirements under the new SES system, this will magically make any one non-government school more affordable for a battling parent? This is fictional nonsense.
It is true to say that these increases in SES funding will result in only modest decreases in school fees. Again, I note that some of the schools in my electorate are amongst the most prestigious and also the most expensive schools in Australia. By and large their fees are well beyond the economic means of all but the most privileged in Australia. The fee reductions from the new SES scheme are likely to be a drop in the ocean compared with the substantive gains that would need to be made to make such schools more affordable to the average parents' children. For working-class Australians, including single-mother families and those on minimum incomes, these amendments present no tangible improvement in choice of education. These people will simply have to take the nearest government school and be content with it.
I say all this with acknowledgment of the outstanding work of non-government schools in making arrangements for those who do not have the economic means to afford the considerable fees that are required to fund the infrastructures of these schools. Education, like anything else on this earth, is a case of `what you pay for is what you get'. I note the considerable efforts to which the wealthier schools go to make their schools affordable to those who would otherwise be economically excluded from such schools. I know of many individual schemes where these schools average out the fees, in effect using the fees structure to level out payments, ranging from payment schemes to a complete waiver of bills in some instances. By and large, the higher category schools simply out-price all but the most affluent. They have truly laudable policies designed to accommodate a wide cross-section of society so that all benefit from the infrastructure they have built over time. I firmly believe that such practices will continue in the future. It will not be the amendments contained in this bill that will achieve the social equity goals which the minister has glossed over as his justification for essentially giving more money to all non-government schools. It will be the selfless policies of the individual schools that seek to act in a truly charitable way in opening their doors to all people who would wish their children to be educated there.
The minister has confused the ultimate end of this bill with the instrument with which he seeks to achieve it. On the one hand he uses a new SES regime which effectively means more money to all schools. Yet the minister's stated reason for doing so is to afford greater access to choice of education. If the minister and this government were truly serious about access to the most appropriate schooling for children, they would accommodate the aspirations and needs of parents and their schools in their desire for policies which reflect the true doctrine of in loco parentis, meaning in the place of the parent. This means that a teacher is the parent for specific purposes. But this government, through its failure to ratify domestic legislation to better interpret the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, has in fact been a silent witness as states continue to ratify legislation which takes more and more power away from the parents.  
I have watched with dismay the corrosion of parental rights in state and federal laws. This government has made great play of so-called parental rights and children's rights. Yet it is in the policy area of education that we have seen perhaps the greatest invasion of parental rights in this country. I speak of the amendments to various state and federal laws, too many to mention here tonight, which have essentially made it so difficult, I say near impossible, for parents' rights in supporting the needs of their children. I cite part of the Commonwealth Programmes for Schools Quadrennial Administrative Guidelines, approved by the minister, which is reproduced in full in the Bills Digest:
A fundamental principle underlying the Commonwealth's role in school education is to support the right of parents to choose the educational environment which best suits the needs of their child, whether the school of their choice is in the government or non--government sector. Choice in schooling leads to diversity which, in turn, allows freedom of expression, accommodates diverse beliefs and values, stimulates innovation and promotes greater accountability for schooling outcomes to parents and to the wider Australian community.
I bring this quote to the House's attention tonight because it is timely to remind ourselves of policies which this government is responsible for in the evolution of domestic laws which have had exactly the opposite intention.
