I speak of the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of the Child. This declaration is an international instrument which this government is a signatory to. It has been used to justify amendments to legislation directly relevant to the bill today. I speak of the group of acts that come under two broad headings, child protection and education reform acts. On this topic I can speak only of New South Wales, but I understand that similar legislation exists in other jurisdictions. 
The use of the UN convention has been sold to the community to protect children. In fact, it has been used to deny parents the right to educate their children, especially in the use of corporal discipline. It is now perilous for a child to be chastised in any way. Any attempt to do so by a teacher is even more perilous. Government schools are universally compelled by law to implement non-corporal discipline codes that directly intervene on the natural choice of the parent in how their child should be disciplined. Non-government schools in New South Wales are now required to sign non-corporal discipline codes in fear of losing their registration status if they do not comply with the now infamous subsection 47(f) of the Education Act 1990 of New South Wales. In doing so, state and federal governments have ignored the broader body of criminal legislation which protects children against criminal offences. They have justified the existence of invasive new laws that trammel parents' rights in the name of children's rights, education reform and child protection legislation. A more correct terminology for these legislative aphorisms is `anti-parental rights'.
I bring these examples to the House's attention tonight to demonstrate the true direction of this present government in doing what it does best when difficult decisions are needed, that is, it either does nothing or flicks the problem to the states. It is the case with the proposed amendments to the in vitro fertilisation debacle and it is the same here with the education legislation. If this government were truly concerned about parental choice in education, it would enact legislation specifically guaranteeing the rights of the child and the rights of parents in separate legislation. Instead, it has sought to do nothing, leaving the states to make the difficult choices of how to implement such legislation. What has happened is that, in the case of New South Wales, state laws have had to contend with the onerous task of interpreting the UN convention by amending children's protection and education reform legislation, often with catastrophic results in terms of parental rights. Parental disciplining rights, a fundamental aspect of parenthood, have been trammelled simply because this government has not had the political will nor courage to define what that convention must mean in the context of domestic legislation. It was Chief Justice Mason, in the High Court decision of Teoh, who alerted the legislature yet again to the fact that UN conventions and other international instruments are not legislation. They are not drafted in the same style. Very often, it is necessary for domestic legislatures and jurisdictions to interpret such instruments to give them legislative effect so that there can be the proper implementation of the spirit of the legislation. 
I am compelled to remind this House of the role of government in education. In particular, it appears necessary to explain to this government what its role in respect of education is. That is, government occupies a mediate role in education. The immediate role to educate has lain, does lie and always will lie in the hands of the parents. What this government is doing is reducing and ultimately eliminating the immediate role of parents to educate by redefining it. I note that the immediate role of parents to educate is a direct function of their unique procreative function. Their role to physically bring the child into this world is hand in glove with their educational and formative role with the child. Indeed, it is not until the child reaches the age of maturity that the role of the parent really ends—if the parental role can ever be said to end. It is for this reason that a parent has the natural powers over the child, including custody, guardianship, access and other powers. These facts are being progressively forgotten by this government. One has to go back to totalitarian regimes of nazism, fascism and communism to hear remarks about the state having a higher role and an immediate role that defeats the natural rights of parents to educate.
I say all this in the context of the minister's guidelines mentioned above. The truth is that this government is, by stealth, taking rights of parents away from their procreative power to educate their children. Fortunately, the public is awake to this trend. This is why there has been an explosion of parent controlled and independent controlled schools. This is why home schooling has also taken off strongly, and the public has risen to the occasion and demanded that such provisions have been imbedded in the various state and federal government instruments.
In New South Wales, we have seen the rapid growth of parents choosing to take their children out of both government and non--government systemic schools, precisely because there is no choice in the level and quality of the education of their children within these systems. It is for this reason that there is still choice in the education system as a whole. If left alone, this government would have further delimited choice in both curriculum and manner of education. Education is a holistic term that is more than the three Rs; it also includes the physical, disciplinary, moral and spiritual development of the child.
It is wrong and deceptive for the minister to describe the legislation in the way he has in his second reading speech. Yes, the funding is welcome for all non-government schools, but I am yet to be convinced that the distribution of income is fair for government schools. On this point I share my party's opposition to this bill in that it is unfair on government schools. However, the greater injustice is that the minister attempts to demonstrate that this bill is somehow fulfilling this government's obligation to parental and family rights, whereas in the broader context of laws and international instruments ratified by this government it has pandered to `one world government' initiatives to take away more power from parents by denying them real choice in how their children are to be educated, particularly with regard to their moral education. The conduct of this government is tantamount to saying, `You are free to educate your children so long as you teach them one type of morality.' 
Where does this leave the minister's statement in his guidelines? I put to this House tonight that the conclusions reached in the Bills Digest are well founded: the bill does fall short in its financial allocation to the government school sector. Whilst this bill is primarily a finance bill, a darker message lies beneath the appropriations. That darker message lies at the heart of the issue of true parental choice in education. The gains made by parents in the state education systems have come at a price for those brave advocates who have fought the federal and state education bureaucracies to win the hard-fought rights of parents to educate. The minister can take no comfort from this appropriation to say that the existence of these rights is the doing of the government. Rather, it is testament to the mums and dads and the non-government and government school sectors that have fought long and hard for the concessions they have won.
Yet even this has not been enough. This government continues to take the rights of children to mean the rights of the state. This government continues to legally separate child from parent. This government continues to obfuscate the meaning of the terms `family' and `parent' so that it is increasingly difficult for parents to exercise any control over their children. This is due in large measure to the misapplication of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child in domestic legislation which has torn families apart in the most culturally insensitive ways. It has lambasted families with specific legislation and denied parents any meaningful control over their children.
Finally, let me say that the minister has misrepresented the intention of this bill. This bill increases non-government school funding across the board. It apologises for this with a purported $1 billion grant over four years to the government school sector. However, let no-one be deceived: in real terms of affording choice to parents, the broader conduct of this government is to take further control over their children away from them and place further power in the hands of the government. That is clearly unacceptable. (Time expired)
debate_title: <title>STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) BILL 2000</title>

name: Andren, Peter, MP
text:
—I want to start by saying that I make these comments on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 2000 as a former teacher in the public school system, with a brother and sisters who have taught in the state system, but also as a parent who exercised choice in sending both boys to an independent school after their early public schooling. This is crucial legislation. It will lay the foundation, for better or worse, for federal involvement in school education at the beginning of the new millennium. It appropriates over $20 billion over the next four years for the purposes of school education. It deserves full and well-informed scrutiny by this place and by all members. It should not be voted for or against by anyone on the basis of party political rhetoric but should be voted on only after thorough analysis. After all, it deals with one of the most important areas, if not the most important area, that we as legislators can deal with—the futures of our children. Yet typically, like so many others that have preceded it, the debate on this bill takes place without the necessary information being put before members of this place. The bill was introduced to the House on 29 June and was immediately referred to the Senate Employment, Workplace Relations, Small Business and Education Legislation Committee. That committee was initially due to report back on 6 September but has now been granted an extension of time to report until 4 October. Once again this place is being asked to pass a crucial piece of legislation before part of this parliament's committee system has scrutinised the bill thoroughly and reported on it.
I welcome the member for Fremantle to the front bench and say that I am pleased to see her in the chamber tonight. As she has said in recent times, such treatment of this place by the executive not only demeans it but makes it largely irrelevant in the democratic process. I congratulate the member for Fremantle for her recognition of the fundamental problems facing our democracy in terms of the manipulation of this place by the major political parties and the manipulation of those parties by big business and others with vested interests. I hope she retains that stance in her new position on the opposition front bench. But I say to her also that perhaps the best way to bring back meaningful debate to this place is either to get enough people on the crossbenches so that the government of the day cannot treat it with the contempt we have become so accustomed to or to be bold enough to recognise that proportional representation is the only fair way to achieve representative democracy. Only then will debate in this place take on real meaning. 
The education resources index has been used since 1985 to calculate the relative levels of funding that non-government schools receive from the Commonwealth. It funds schools on the basis of their relative need by comparing the income the school is able to generate on its own behalf with a standard level of resource based on the cost of educating each student at a government school. As an indicator, it is therefore primarily concerned with the capacity of a school to raise funds on its own behalf. It has 12 different categories of funding, with category 1 schools receiving the least assistance. The most common criticism of the ERI—and I have seen it in my dealings with schools in Calare—is that schools servicing the same kinds of communities do not receive the same level of funding. 
The Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs 1998 report on the SES simulation project cites the examples of Launceston and Canberra as two areas where schools serving largely the same communities receive widely different funding under the ERI. In Canberra's case, it has non-government schools funded in categories 2, 3, 6, 8, 10 and 11. The situation in Canberra is not dissimilar to that in Calare where, even after some recent reclassifications, schools servicing students drawn from largely the same communities receive different levels of funding. Another criticism of the ERI is that, by reducing government funding as private income rises, the scheme actually acts as a disincentive for non-government schools to seek greater private contributions. A further criticism is that the review process is not responsive enough and, in particular when a school seeks reclassification, as has happened recently to many schools because of the rural decline, the process is simply too bureaucratic and not transparent enough.
There is little doubt that the educational resources index as a method for calculating funding for non-government schools has passed its use-by date and requires either an overhaul or replacement. The question is whether the proposed SES model will provide a better way of funding non-government schools in terms of equity, certainty, simplicity and flexibility. The SES funding method will assess a school's need according to a measure of the socioeconomic status of the community or communities from which it draws its students. The SES is a statistical measure of the socioeconomic profile of a community. It is made up of a number of different aspects, including income, occupational status and educational status. Whereas the ERI aims to assess the capacity of a school to generate funds on its own behalf, the SES will assess a school's need by measuring the capacity of the community it draws from to support it. It works as follows. Students' home addresses will be collected, then linked into the Bureau of Statistics census collection districts data, which typically comprises about 250 households, and an SES index will then be applied to calculate the average SES score for each school community. Each school's SES score will then be calculated on the basis of the average SES of the communities from which its students are drawn and weighted according to the number of students from each census district at the school. The lower the SES score of a school community, the lower its capacity to support its school will be judged and the more government funding it will be entitled to. The SES method will return results in a way similar to how IQs are measured. An average school will return an SES score of 100. A school servicing a disadvantaged community will receive a score below 85. A school servicing our most affluent communities will return a score of 130. 
So how does the SES system compare to the ERI? The simulation of the SES model conducted in 1998 by the Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs covered 2,262 of the 2,519 non-government schools across Australia—not a bad sample. Given the thoroughness of that report, I have no reason to doubt the department's finding that the study was soundly based. The simulation returned SES scores ranging from 56 to 135. Schools with SESs at the lower end of the scale included those servicing communities with a large Aboriginal population and other schools servicing remote areas or certain metropolitan areas. Most of these were Catholic systemic schools. Schools returning scores at the other end of the scale were generally located in metropolitan areas well known for their high socioeconomic status. While the range of scores was high, of the 2,262 schools involved in the simulation well over half of them returned scores of between 105 and 90, 53 per cent of the schools scored below 100, while only 10 per cent of schools returned scores in excess of 115.
The simulation project's report went on to compare the SES measurements against the then current ERI categories. It found that, while under the ERI 76 per cent of schools were in the neediest funding categories, under the SES model there was a greater concentration in the middle ranges. The comparison shows that many schools assessed as needy or not needy under the ERI were similarly assessed under the SES simulation. The largest number of schools with SES scores above 115 were found in ERI category 1. The largest number of schools with SES scores below 85 were found in ERI categories 11 and 12. The problem appears to be in the middle, in ERI categories 6 to 10, where the SES modelling found relatively little difference between the communities being serviced but, under the ERI, the schools were receiving substantially different funding.
It is important to note that, for each of the ERI categories, SES scores were returned across a large range. For example, ERI category 2 schools returned scores ranging from 100 to 135—that is, from average to very affluent. Category 3 schools returned SES scores ranging from 90 to 130—that is, from a fair way below average to very affluent. Category 6 through 11 schools returned very similar SES scores, ranging from 90 to 120. For a comparison of these two systems, it is again interesting to look at the results from the Canberra region. The 35 non-government schools receiving ERI funding that participated in the study, ranging from categories 2 through to 11, all returned SES scores above the average, in the range 110 to126. These results suggest that some of those schools were receiving a larger than fair share of public funding on the basis of the relative capacity of the communities from which they drew support.
The government has made much of the broad support that the non-government sector has given the proposed SES model. But, as the simulation project shows, if the SES results were to be applied literally, many schools would have their funding altered substantially. Those that would have had their funding reduced would no doubt have objected to it. So it is important to note that, when the government says it has widespread support in the non-government sector, it is actually because all schools have been promised that they will be no worse off under these changes. The widespread support for the change in the non-government system is perhaps also due to the fact that the SES system will not apply to Catholic schools, not in this quadrennium anyway. It will not apply because, shortly before the results of the simulation report were released in December 1998, the government promised to ensure that the Catholic system received category 11 funding for all of its schools. 
I recognise the political difficulties involved in putting in place measures which might reduce funding to some schools. However, given that under the proposed scheme private income earned by all schools will be disregarded, one wonders whether all non--government schools can reasonably expect to get increased funding as well as having open slather on raising other income. One of the valid criticisms of the SES funding system is that, while students attending a school might live in an area with a low socioeconomic status score, they themselves come from a family with a high socio-economic background. For example, if you take the Kings School in Sydney, which draws many students from regional areas, one might expect it to receive a relatively low SES score. Yet it could be argued that it draws from the most affluent families in those low SES regional areas. This criticism strikes at the core of the validity of the SES system as a mechanism for measuring a school's need. While the simulation report stresses that the SES was never intended to measure an individual household's wealth, one wonders how fair a system which does not do that at all can be.
I suggest such a result is unfair and wonder whether some second-tier test is required, perhaps looking at the number of students from a school with an SES below 85 who are in receipt of the youth allowance. The youth allowance means test now gives an accurate picture of individual family's incomes and the figures should be readily available to the department. A school returning an SES of under 85 but with few students on youth allowance would then be subjected to a second level of assessment. I hope the Senate committee looks at ways of amending the bill to ensure that this unfair aspect of the proposed change is removed. 
The other area of concern I hope the committee will give close consideration to is the proposal under the SES scheme to ignore altogether a school's capacity to earn private income. It strikes me that such an arrangement keeps the playing field in somewhat of a level state but then issues spikes to the students from the more affluent school communities, thus increasing the gap at an accelerating rate between the richer schools and those below average, not to mention the gap between those affluent schools and the public sector. At this stage, I cannot see how this treatment can be justified for the most affluent schools with their greater capacity to raise funds.
In recent times, the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs has made much of the record levels of funding the government is providing to government schools. He has indeed claimed that over the next four years his government will spend almost a billion dollars more on public schools than has been spent in the previous four years. The true story is not in the dollar amounts but in the percentage of Commonwealth education payments going to each sector. In 1996, 2,221,557 or 71 per cent of students attended Australian government schools while the other 29 per cent, a little over 900,000, attended non-government schools. That year, 41½  per cent of total specific purpose education payments went to the government sector, while the other 58½ per cent went to non-government schools. That equated to Commonwealth funding of $606 per government student and $2,107 per non-government student.
By 1999, the number of students in government schools had increased to 2.247 million and in non-government schools to a little over 978,000—70 per cent and 30 per cent respectively. In 1999 compared to 1996, each student in the government sector was being funded an extra $103, representing a 17 per cent increase, while each student in the non-government sector was receiving $495, an extra 23½ per cent. According to forward estimates by the Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs, by 2003, each student in the government system will receive $792 from the Commonwealth, while each student in the non-government sector will receive $3,314. That will represent a 30.7 per cent increase per student for the government sector and a 52½ per cent increase per student for the non-government sector. These funding shifts appear to be outpacing the slight drift in students from government to non-government schools over the past three years, which is used as justification for these increases. 
Part of the problem with this area of policy is the difficulty in pinning down exactly what is happening with funding. Like the health system, the fact that there is no clear responsibility between state and federal governments for school education makes it hard to know who to believe. It is not as simple as the member for Corangamite would have it—a matter of choice. While those with the means can choose their school, state schools cannot benefit from the affluence of their suburb or town except in a very marginal way. When you look at the figures, it is fair to say that, while funding for both sectors may be increasing, funding for the private sector is increasing by more not only in dollar terms but also in percentage terms.
Given that the proposed socioeconomic status assessment system will not apply to systemic schools, given the commitment that no non-government school will be worse off under the SES system and given that even the most affluent non-government schools will receive a funding boost and be free to earn private income as they wish without it having any impact on their public funding, it seems fair to draw the conclusion that, from the federal perspective at least, the SES method is likely to further widen the comparative federal funding gap between government and non--government schools.
I noted with interest the member for Parramatta's comments last night that parents of students from non-government schools pay taxes which provide revenue to a public education system their children will never access. The implication was that, because they pay taxes, they deserve to get some of that back to help their own children. I do not agree with that argument in all cases. People pay taxes for a whole range of reasons, whether it is for aged pensions, Newstart, Austudy, drug rehabilitation, research, the health system or, dare I say, to support politicians in their retirement. People pay taxes for all of these services which they might never themselves access. One of the most fundamental purposes of paying taxes, as far as I am concerned, is to provide as good an education as we can to all Australians, regardless of their means.
As I argued in my speeches on the aged care reforms, I do not care if people want to pay $100,000 bonds to enter a five-star Moran nursing home in an affluent area, but I want to ensure we have at least a three-star service across the rest of the sector. The same applies to education. Our available resources should first be directed at supporting the quality of a basic education. I doubt anyone can say the public sector with its class sizes and social and economic disadvantages is anywhere near three-star across the board. That, in essence, is the difficulty I have with this bill. At least to the degree that funding increases do not match cross-over to the independent sector, it appears to misdirect scarce public resources. I fought hard, and with success, for equity for transitional emergency funding between independent schools in my own electorate. I know they are generous in the scholarships they offer to the less well off, but my larger duty is to seek equity across the total education field, in all sectors. To the extent I have outlined, I think there are major flaws in the states grants formula. So, with the serious reservations that I have outlined and without knowing the results of the Senate inquiry, I am reluctant to support the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill as it stands at this stage. I expect substantial amendments that will address some of the problem areas I have identified before this bill returns to the House, and then let the minister argue why those amendments should not be made.

name: Latham, Mark, MP
text:
—I rise to speak on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 2000. The oldest and most poisonous issue in our nation's politics is state aid. One of the proudest achievements of the Australian Labor Party is its resolution of this issue in the 1970s. Through the establishment of the Schools Commission in 1973, the Whitlam government gave full and fair funding to the non-government sector. It established the principle of needs based funding. All schools, whether public or private, religious or non-sectarian, in the city or the country, were to be judged and funded on the basis of need. This bill is a perversion of this great principle. It reopens the bitter wounds of state aid and sectarianism in our society. It delivers a special deal to the Catholic school system—a deal which cannot be justified in terms of either education equity or public administration.
While other parts of the non-government sector are to be funded on a school by school basis according to the new SES formula, the Catholic system will maintain its block grants, to be administered and distributed centrally by the Catholic Education Commission in each state and territory. Uniquely in the sector, the 1,700 Catholic schools in Australia will remain with the old ERI funding system. I cannot support this special deal. In terms of education policy, there is no reason why the Catholic schools should have funding rules different from the rest of the non-government sector. The resolution of the state aid controversy was supposed to deliver Catholic schools a fair deal, not a special deal. Special deals are antipathetic to the whole principle of needs based funding for our schools. In this instance, the government is applying a weaker standard of transparency and public accountability to the Catholic system than to the remainder of the non-government sector. While the Anglican, independent and Christian schools will have their funding distributed on a publicly accountable school by school basis, the Catholic schools will receive a block grant. Taxpayers will not know how this money is distributed and used.
As the Senate committee examining this bill discovered two weeks ago, the federal department does not ask for the detail of Catholic school funding. That was the admission—that the federal department does not ask for the detail of Catholic school funding. It is a disgraceful situation to have two different standards for the use of public money in the non-government school sector. It may even be in breach of Australia's antidiscrimination laws. Why should a Catholic school be treated differently from an Anglican school or a Muslim school or an independent school? Religious discrimination is one of the most sickening practices in any society, yet our national government is enshrining it in legislation. Not even government MPs can explain away this double standard.
In the past I have had cause to support the member for Parramatta in his campaign to apply rigour and discipline to government outlays in rural Australia. The member for Parramatta has declared himself to be an opponent of special deals and pork-barrelling. Speaking on this bill last night, however, these standards deserted him. This is how he explained the government's decision to devise special rules for the Catholic schools:
That request was acceded to by the minister on the commonsense grounds that it would provide them with exactly what they requested ...
Let me repeat that for the benefit of the House:
That request was acceded to by the minister on the commonsense grounds that it would provide them with exactly what they requested ...
This is the commonsense on schools funding, Liberal style. It reminds me of the old drinking song, `We're here because we're here because we're here because we're here.' This is a scam of the first order. I am sure many members will be wondering how the parliament could have arrived at this position. 
Let me provide some insights from my time as shadow minister for education. Prior to the October 1998 election, the Catholic Education Commission tried to engage both sides of politics in a bidding war for Catholic school funding. On the government side, the negotiations appeared quite complex indeed. On 13 August 1998, the coalition parties announced their new taxation package, including the introduction of a goods and services tax. Shortly afterwards, the Australian Financial Review reported that government MPs had met with a number of bishops. One of these gatherings, organised by the member for Lindsay, involved 20 MPs, two archbishops and three bishops. If it was not so serious, you would think it was an Irish joke. I understand that issues such as the GST, native title and education funding were on the table for negotiation and, in some cases, intimidation. One bishop reported in the newspaper that a senior Liberal had threatened to attack the Catholic Church with paedophilia allegations.
This shameful campaign seems to have been successful. During the 1993 election campaign, the Catholic Church, led by its Social Welfare Commission, opposed the inequities of the GST. One might have expected the same thing to happen in 1998. On 21 August, however, eight days after the policy's launch, the Archbishop of Melbourne, George Pell, announced:
... the tax package is a serious attempt to address the problems of an ailing tax system. There is no one Catholic position on an issue as complex as taxation. Tax reform is needed, the (current) system is inequitable.
The Prime Minister, of course, has been quoting the archbishop ever since. Indeed, on 20 September 1998, Mr Howard announced the government's decision to move the Catholic system into the category 11 funding band, thereby committing the Commonwealth to an additional $100 million per annum. The departmental documents assessing the need for such a recategorisation have never been publicly released. As the ALP spokesman at the time, I wanted to match this funding quantum but not necessarily tie it to the Catholic schools. The $100 million per annum should have been available to all schools. Its distribution should have been determined by a thorough needs based assessment. Unfortunately this position was not reflected in our policy documents. After the election, I did not recontest my position on the front bench. To borrow the words of Luther:
   Here I stand; I could do no other.
I remain opposed to special funding deals in education. They undermine the fundamental principle of needs based funding. They cause rivalries and resentment between sectors and between systems. They pit schools against each other, not on the basis of need but according to their political muscle and clout. They allow the powerful to prosper and the weak to be marginalised. They allow politicians to be corrupted and decision making to be perverted. Worst of all, in terms of schools policy, they undermine the historic settlement of the state aid debate. The minister for education, Dr Kemp, has embarked on a dangerous divide and rule agenda for the funding of Australia's schools. His special deal with the Catholic system reflects his determination to play politics with the education of young Australians.
This is one of the sickest things I have seen in federal politics, and the Catholic system has been ill advised indeed to play along. They are destroying the credibility of their own funding system. They are undermining the very basis of state aid: the fair and full funding of non-government schools. They are fouling their own nest. Ultimately, however, it is not the members of the Catholic Education Commission who will suffer most; the real victims will be the children attending Catholic schools. Not only is this deal wrong in terms of education policy and process, it sells short the funding needs of Catholic schools. Sadly for these schools, the backroom deal has backfired. The federal department has now advised members that, if the Catholics had joined the new SES system, they would have received an extra $240 million per annum—$140 million more than the amount they settled on. The parents of children in Catholic schools should be screaming blue murder about this injustice. The Catholic Education Commission was desperate to maintain its centralised control of school funding rather than move to a publicly accountable, school by school system. As Rev. Tom Doyle told the Senate committee on 22 August: 
   The Catholic systems would have actually benefited more from an aggregation according to SES levels but in fact we opted, in negotiation with the government, to stay at level 11 in order to preserve the systemic nature of funding for Catholic schools.
What a remarkable admission. Doyle is willing to receive less federal funding, less support for Catholic schools, on the basis that he maintains control of the distribution. Imagine the outcry if members in this place said they were willing to accept less money for schools in their electorates in return for having control of the funds. Imagine the outcry if the second biggest school system in Australia, the New South Wales government schools, wilfully and deliberately missed out on $140 million of federal funding. There would be calls for the New South Wales education minister and departmental head to resign. Why should a different standard of performance apply to the Catholic Education Commission?
Rev. Doyle is also operating on a false premise: school by school SES funding would not threaten the systemic nature of Catholic schools. In every respect the system would remain in place. Its employment of teachers, its organisation of teaching materials, its framing of the curriculum and its testing and assessment of students—its core work would be unaffected by this change. The only change would be in the funding methodology: the distribution of public money would be determined by a nationally consistent and equitable formula rather than by Rev. Doyle and his colleagues at the commission. As government members are keen to point out, Rev. Doyle has actually praised the new SES system as being fair and open to scrutiny. This begs the question, of course: if the new system is so good, why isn't the Catholic Education Commission joining up? Why has it refused to join? I suspect that Rev. Doyle wants other publicly funded schools to be open to scrutiny but not his own. Perhaps he takes his inspiration from St Augustine, who said, `Lord, make me chaste and continent, but not just yet.'
I appeal directly to Catholic parents to right this wrong. I say to them: your education commission has let down you and your children. They have robbed your schools of $140 million each year for no other purpose than keeping power and control in their own hands. You should demand that your schools join the SES system and receive their rightful amount of federal funding. This is not only a debate about due process and accountability. There is strong evidence, especially in New South Wales and Queensland, that the Catholic education commissions do not distribute their public funding equitably. For a number of years, parish priests covering my electorate have complained about the underfunding of their schools. Funds are distributed on a per capita basis to each diocese. Redistribution takes place only within each district. Obviously this disadvantages schools in western and south-western Sydney compared with the North Shore. It is unacceptable for taxpayers to contribute $2 billion dollars annually to Catholic schools without any guarantee of its equitable distribution.
This is not a standard the parliament applies to any other area of public expenditure. Imagine the outcry if the Aboriginal affairs minister could not detail the allocation of funds in his portfolio. Imagine the controversy if the education minister could not report to the parliament on the funding received by each Australian university. Why should the Catholic Education Commission be exempt from proper standards of public accountability, transparency and distribution? As long as the Catholic system operates under a special deal, the situation can only get worse. At the Senate committee, Mrs Temby from the Commission was asked about the prospects of Catholic schools at the end of the current funding period. She replied as follows: 
   At the end of the quadrennium it will be another discussion.
Another discussion with the government—that is, another opportunity for cutting a deal, another opportunity for a bidding war between the major parties. For those of us who want state aid to work, this is an absolute tragedy. The funding of non-government schools was never supposed to end up this way. State aid was not supposed to be a system in which a particular church throws its weight around and negotiates a special deal with the government. In some respects we have created a monster. The political system is unwilling to say no to the Catholic Education Commission. It has become one of the untouchables of Australian politics.
I am sure some MPs will be a little startled by my approach in this debate. They probably see politics as an exercise in coalition building—strapping one interest group onto another and hoping to form an electoral majority. They probably assume that the Catholic Church wields substantial electoral clout, placing it beyond challenge in a two-party system. I believe that these assumptions perpetuate the myths of the old politics. The information age is driving a new politics—one characterised by the flattening of hierarchies and the dispersal of information. New technologies are wiping out the middle person and are empowering the individual. In a better educated and skilled society, people are wanting to make more of their own judgments and to take more control of their own interests and entitlements. They have less respect and less time for large hierarchical organisations. They want power to be dispersed to the many, not concentrated in the hands of the unaccountable few.
The Catholic Church is, in general, a victim of these trends. It is losing popular faith and public support. The Catholic Education Commission in particular is an example of a flawed and authoritarian hierarchy. In the new politics, I believe it is a paper tiger—trying to bluff the political system and hang on to its concentrated power and funding. This is the classic case of an insider trying to exercise power at the expense of outsiders—the parents, students and teachers who, under the present system, have no say in the allocation of Catholic school funding. This parliament should not protect the rights of insiders; it should enfranchise the participation of outsiders. We should appeal directly to the parish schools and expose the disadvantage they are suffering under the Catholic Education Commission. We should highlight the authoritarianism of the commission and the gross inequities of its actions. Moreover, we should condemn this government as a government of special deals—deals to buy off rural industries, deals on digital TV, and now the perversion of school funding for the non-government sector.
I am absolutely certain that the parents and teachers in the Catholic system will respond positively to this approach. They want their public representatives to stand up for a fair deal, not for the entrenched interests of an education hierarchy. These parents and teachers cannot afford to miss out on $140 million in funding—the equivalent of a seven per cent funding cut. Imagine the outcry if some other set of schools was losing seven per cent of their potential funding. That is what the Catholic Education Commission has inflicted upon themselves. It is an absolute scam. These parents and teachers cannot afford to give their children anything but the very best start in life. In short, they cannot afford this government's special deals. The parliament should have just one priority in schools funding: the needs of students. This should not be about party politics or the interests of education administrators, and it should not be about political power or backroom deals. 
I feel sick in the stomach, quite frankly, to know that parish schools in my electorate are going to miss out because of this deal and that they are going to be short-changed in this fashion. They are needy schools. I am a supporter of state aid. I want those schools to get a better deal, to receive more funding, to provide a better education for working-class communities in my electorate. How am I supposed to feel knowing that their commission has done them out of seven per cent of their funding? It is an outrage, and I will be communicating that directly to every school and every parent in the Catholic system that I can find in my constituency.  
I feel saddened to know that this bill undermines the principles of state aid and, in the absolute madness of Dr Kemp, is likely to reopen this terrible debate. I urge the Catholic Education Commission to reconsider the folly of its approach. It is fouling its own nest. It needs to rethink the deal it has formulated with this government. It needs to reconsider the folly of what it has done. This is not a happy occasion for schools funding. This is not a proper bill for the non-government sector. This, I believe, takes the education funding debate in this country back several decades to when non-government schools were not treated fairly, were not treated on the basis of need, and were not given a fair deal by the federal government of their day.
For this government to play politics, to manipulate and to cut special deals, all for crass electoral advantage—or what they thought was electoral advantage—is one of the lowest moments in the history of this House of Representatives.

name: Snowdon, Warren, MP
text:
—I listened with interest to the remarks of the member for Werriwa on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 2000. Whilst I am not sure that I agree with everything he said, I think there is a great deal of substance in the general message he gave. I was particularly attracted by the view that what we should be doing in this parliament is providing resources based on the needs of students. I say that in the context of this legislation. I make reference to the Bills Digest and take a moment of the House's time to read two paragraphs from it. It says:
   The Bill continues to implement the Government's policy in schooling aimed at giving families `greater choice in selecting which school best meets their children's needs'. The Government's choice and equity policy was first implemented in the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1996. Firstly by the abolition of the New Schools Policy which lifted restrictions on the number of new non-government schools; and secondly by the introduction of the Enrolment Benchmark Adjustment (EBA) scheme which changed the formula for funding to government schools. These initiatives are widely interpreted as Government support of the non-government sector at the expense of government schools. 
Hear, hear! The bill implements a number of decisions made in the 1999-2000 budget, and they are outlined in the Bills Digest. It refers particularly to the socioeconomic status based model, and it says that it is debatable how effectively the SES model will achieve its objectives of supposedly serving the needs of the neediest schools in the community. It says further:
   Evidence presented to the Senate Employment, Workplace Relations, Small Business and Education Legislation Committee suggests that wealthier non-government schools will receive higher funding than poorer schools, including Catholic systemic schools—
about which my colleague the member for Werriwa spoke. It continues:
   Catholic systemic schools will not be funded by an SES rating but will have a system funding level which preserves their year 2000 funding categories. Such an agreement honours the Government's 1998 election commitment to the Catholic systems.
I was not privy to the deal about which my colleague spoke, but I would say that he raises some very significant questions about the level of funding going to needy Catholic schools in the private school system. 
I want to make an observation about remarks made on this legislation by Ian Morgan. In an article in the Age on Wednesday, 30 August, Morgan writes: 
Dr Kemp has attempted to defend these measures as equity measures. 
This is a reference to the content of the bill. The article continues:
But well over 80 per cent of the students from the major equity target groups—students from low socioeconomic status families, students of indigenous origin, students from rural and remote areas, and students with disabilities—are enrolled in government schools. The new bill directs money preferentially to the non-government sector, which under-enrols these students.
   The real agenda is `competition and choice', code words for an agenda of markets in schooling, increased privatisation of provision, and increased privatisation of costs. The flaw in educational markets is obvious. They allow the already advantaged through wealth and influence to increase their advantages at the expense of the disadvantaged.
And I say: hear, hear! I might point out that, in the case of the Northern Territory, we are, without doubt, statistically the most disadvantaged of all Australians in relation to this bill because the highest proportion of our students are in government schools. In 1999, 77.5 per cent of the 36,000-plus students were in government schools, against a national average of 69.7 per cent. This figure is the highest of any state or territory—the next highest being Tasmania at 75.1 per cent. That rings alarm bells for me. I analyse the performance results of students in the schools and I look at the benchmark used in this place and elsewhere in the community for year 12 retention rates. In 1999, the Northern Territory had the lowest year 12 retention rates at 48.2 per cent for male students and 57.8 per cent for females, which were against a national average of 68.4 per cent for males and 79.5 per cent for females—the Northern Territory was 20 percentage points less in performance for both males and females. Of course, if you look in more detail at those figures, you discover that in the case of the split between indigenous and non-indigenous students, the figures are even more dramatic. I have figures for 1997—because I do not have the figures for 1999—and they indicate that the retention rate for indigenous students in year 12 in the Northern Territory was 9.4 per cent against 54.5 per cent for non-indigenous students. I think that there would not be a person in this House who would not believe that those figures are damning—and they are. We are seeing here an approach to funding of schools which will provide the richest families and the richest schools in Australia with pocketfuls of money out of the public purse, the purpose of which we are not sure of but it is supposed to provide some sort of equity. 
I note in a press release from the shadow education minister that in fact the disparities are very obvious. What I am concerned about, not least of which is the argument presented by my friend the member for Werriwa, is the impact that this will have on the community. I have lived and worked in Northern Australia for 25 years. For some of that time I was a schoolteacher. I have been chair of a school council. Three of my children attend public schools and another of my children attends a private school. All the private schools in the Northern Territory, bar one, are categories 10 and 12 schools, so they are at the bottom end of the spectrum. They are unlikely to benefit from this legislation to the same degree as Carey Grammar or other great private schools. What is of concern to me is that we are not going to get the outcomes that we require for public education and the bulk of our community's students by moving money out of the public education system directly into the private education system—as is being done here through this legislation. 
We hear in this place a lot about practical reconciliation. These are, in my view, government weasel words that somehow try to elevate the fact that they are barely carrying out their basic responsibility to all citizens to the level of special measures for indigenous Australians. In the Northern Territory, the government does not even bother with this subterfuge. It has a continuing history of shifting funds away from the most disadvantaged sector—remote area Aboriginal schools—and propping up urban schools in Darwin, Katherine and Tennant Creek. That could be justified if, in fact, you thought the funds were coming from another source to those schools in the bush. We need to understand that, if you move outside the spine of the Stuart Highway, away from the major mining towns, there are no high schools in any of the Aboriginal communities out there—and we wonder why the educational outcomes for indigenous students are as they are. We know that the public schools in remote communities in the Northern Territory do not have anything near the equivalent degree or quality of resources that their urban counterparts have, let alone as compared to Carey Grammar or Kings School in Parramatta or Geelong Grammar. Each of those schools will get something around $800,000 out of this exercise. The poor bush schools will get $4,000 apiece. I say that that is neither fair nor equitable, but most of all it goes well beyond the criteria elucidated by my friend the member for Werriwa on the allocation of funds on the basis of need. It is very clear that if we are to improve the educational outcomes for indigenous and other Australians who live in remote communities and in the bush we need to dedicate substantially more resources to them. I fear that this is not going to happen whilst we have this government in office. 
What we know in the Northern Territory is that they have been cutting funds to government schools. The current minister for education in the Northern Territory could be more aptly described as the `minister for slash and burn'. He is holding back 20 per cent of school budgets and he has left 50 school teacher vacancies unfilled. In one area of north-east Arnhem Land they are 27 teachers short. 
We need to understand that we are not now talking about Carey Grammar School or Geelong Grammar School; we are talking about remote bush schools where there are not only shortages of teacher resources but also shortages of capital. We do not have high schools. There is a shortage of infrastructure. The sorts of outcomes that we would want these children to achieve are simply not possible because the resources are just not available. Yet we have the Northern Territory government on the one hand, and now the federal government on the other, effectively denying them access to the resources that the taxpayer makes available to us in the form of revenue to this government and to the governments generally for the purpose of public education. What we are doing instead is shifting bucket loads of this money into the pockets of the wealthier schools in Australia.
I noted with interest the comments made by Justice Vincent from Victoria which were read out today in the parliament by the shadow minister for education. I will not repeat them here. What we also need to know is that, if we want to get effective educational outcomes in these remote community schools, we need to provide teachers with the resources that they require. And part of those resources is that they also require are decent living conditions, decent housing. We know that absolutely no effort has been made by this government or by the Northern Territory government to provide them with appropriate housing, so that many teachers live in demountables. They live in demountables, which I am sure you and I would not care to live in, Mr Deputy Speaker, and which would be regarded as a health hazard if they were in a major urban community. You certainly would not see them on the grounds of Carey Grammar. What we know about these places is that the roofs leak, the plumbing and the wiring breaks down, and people's furniture and other belongings get covered in mould. This does not happen at Carey Grammar. The contrast could not be starker. 
I feel for the students in these communities, because they aspire to decent educational outcomes. Their parents aspire to decent educational outcomes. Most of these communities, certainly most remote Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory, rely on CDEP as the form of income support for the community. They are not wealthy communities. In the past I have spoken at length in this place about the comparative disadvantage that such communities suffer as a result of their isolation, higher costs and lower income levels when compared with urban communities such as Sydney and Melbourne. It becomes very obvious when you look at schools such as I described earlier: Carey Grammar, Geelong Grammar, Kings School at Parramatta, Scotch College in Melbourne and Adelaide, Knox Grammar, Presbyterian Ladies College and Brighton Grammar School. Just look at the contrast and ask: how can this government justify shifting the public resources that they are seeking to shift in this legislation into those schools as opposed to putting them directly where they are most required—the needier students in Australia, these students who live in these very remote Aboriginal communities? 
I thought that, when I came to this place, what I would be doing would be sitting around with others of like mind, not necessarily agreeing on points of principle but at least having a reasonable go at coming to an agreement about what is best for the community. I have heard no argument coming from the government that could convince me—or anyone I know—of the validity of the course of action which the government is seeking to take in this legislation. It will not add to educational outcomes for those people most in need. It will not improve the year 12 retention levels for Aboriginal students in the Northern Territory or the wider Northern Territory school proportion because of the very large proportion of the Northern Territory's school population that goes to public schools. In any event, as I pointed out, not one of the private schools in the Northern Territory is a category 1 school—not one.
It seems to me that, if it is the purpose of members in this place to develop good policy and make good legislation for the people of Australia, then this sadly misses the mark. I am happy to enter into dialogue with members of the government on the best way to achieve and improve educational attainment levels for people in remote Australia. But I have not seen them want to engage in such dialogue. What we have seen here is an ideological fix trumped-up by Minister Kemp 10 years ago, paraded now as government policy and exhibited here in the form of this pernicious piece of legislation that will just create further division within our community. That is not good for us: it is not good for this parliament and it is not good for Australia. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

name: Forrest, John, MP
text:
—I would like to take this opportunity to address an issue which I know will be dear to your heart, Mr Speaker, and that is the publication of the draft basin salinity management strategy for the Murray-Darling Basin. This document has been a long time coming, but we are pleased that it is now out in the public domain for public comment. I am urging all those people with an interest in the issue, of which there are many in the constituency of Mallee, to study this document and to make public comment, which is due by 5 December this year.  
 There are two initiatives in the strategy to tackle the problem of salinity which is so evident right across the Murray-Darling Basin. It is still very much a skeletal framework document which leaves a lot of work yet to be done to put some flesh on the bones, but at least it sets out some very substantial objectives in order to overcome this very pernicious problem that pervades right across the Murray-Darling Basin. It actually affects 18 constituencies of this place. It is a very large part of Australia—one-seventh of the continent, about one million square kilometres, producing about 41 per cent of the nation's horticultural and agricultural wealth. It is a very important issue to the nation. 
The central thrust of the strategy is to focus on an integrated catchment management approach to solving our problems. One thing that I think we can be proud of in this place and as a nation is that this will be the largest catchment management program of its kind in the whole world. It is over a million square kilometres. It is important to note that there are many countries around the world that look with great interest on what we are achieving here in Australia in terms of getting all of the state agencies together in a ministerial council to tackle the very serious problems that confront us.
A lot of people are already asking how much it will cost to overcome this pernicious problem we have with salinity and water management. That is a matter that we have yet to establish, but it is certainly in the billions of dollars. It will be a great challenge for this parliament and the government to meet that need. 
I am particularly interested in tackling the very serious, and probably awkward, political difficulties in encouraging the amount and the degree of community, government and state involvement in solving our problem. We are all in this boat together. It is not a question of laying blame. The salinity problems in the Murray-Darling Basin have not just happened; it has taken us 120-odd years to see the damage that is now evident. I would not propose that it take us that long to fix it, but it is a very long-term commitment to overcome some of the degradation that has now occurred—unbelievably complex degradation of the biology of our rivers and streams, and massive salinisation because of the incredibly changed nature of the water flows of those valuable rivers and streams right across the basin. There are at least 21 separate rivers and thousands of other streams.
I think that Australia has probably had its wake-up call on this matter. We have had 12 years of sustained low rainfall. The parlous state of the capacity of many of the storages across the basin gives testimony to that, as well as the parlous state of the nature of our rivers and streams. A lot of people say it is all the farmers' fault, with their land management practices and the inappropriate use of water. But it is not the solution just to find people to blame. The nation has benefited immensely from the agricultural investment that has gone on in the last 15 years, and there has been a massive change in the culture of the use of water and the way that land is managed. (Time expired)
